Play details
Ram-Alley. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1611. Date first performed: 1608. RAM-ALLEY: Or Merrie-Trickes. A COMEDY Actorum nomina.
Sir Oliuer Smale-shankes. Iustice Tutchin. Thomas Smale-shankes. William Smalshankes. Boutcher. Lieftenant Beard. Throte. Captaine Face. Dash. Three Gentlemen. A Drawer. Constable and Officers. Women. Lady Sommerfield, Constantia Somerfield. Francis. Taffata. Adriana, Chamber-maide.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Adriana Thomas Boucher Constantia Somerfield Captain Dash William Smallshanks Francis Thomas Smallshanks Throte Lieutenant Beard Justice Tutchin Captain Puffe Lady Sommerfield Vi, Officer Sir Oliver Smallshanks Prologue/Epilogue Drawer Captain Face Sergeant Taffata 1 Gentleman Servingman 2 Gentleman Combined speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: The Prologue.
sp.l: Home-bred mirth our Muse doth sing,
The Satyrs tooth and Waspish sting,
Which most do hurt when least suspected,
By this Play are not affected;
But if Conceit with quick-turned Scenes,
Observing all those ancient streams,
Which from the Horse-foot fount do flow,
As Time, Place, Person, and to show,
Things never done with that true life,
That thoughts and wits shall stand at strife,
Whether the things now shown be true,
Or whether we ourselves now do
The things we but present: if these
Free from the loathsome stage disease,
(So overworn, so tired and stale,
Not Satyring but to rail,)
May win your favours, and inherit
But calm acceptance for his merit:
He vows by Paper, Pen and Ink,
And by the learned Sisters drink,
To spend his Time, his Lamps, his Oil,
And never cease his brain to toil,
Till from the silent hours of night,
He doth produce for your delight,
Conceits so new, so harmless free,
That Puritans themselves may see
A Play, yet not in public Preach,
That Players such lewd doctrine teach
That their pure joints do quake and tremble,
When they do see a man resemble
The Picture of a Villain: This
As he a friend to Muses is,
To you by me he gives his word,
Is all his Play doth now afford.

div2.stage:
Actus 1. Scæna 1,
Enter Constantia sola, with a letter in her hand.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: In this disguise, (ere scarce my mourning robes)
Could have a general note, I have forsook,
My shape, my mother, and those rich demeans,
Of which I am sole heir, and now resolve,
In this disguise of Page to follow him,
Whose love first caused me to assume this shape.
Lord how my feminine blood stirs at the sight
Of these same breeches, methinks this codpiece
Should betray me: well, I will try the worst,
Hither they say he usually doth come,
Whom I so much affect, what makes he here
In the skirts of Holborne, so near the field,
And at a garden house, he has some punk
Upon my life: no more here he comes.
God save you sir: your name unless I err,
Is master Thomas Boutcher.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: It is sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: From whom is it,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The inside sir will tell you: I shall see
What love he bears me now.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Thou art welcome boy.
How does the fair Constantia Somerfield,
My noble mistress.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I left her in health.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: She gives thee here good words, and for her sake,
Thou shalt not want a master, be mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I thank you sir: now shall I see the Punk.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Who knocks so fast? I thought it was you, what news.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: You know my business well, I sing one song.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Foot, what would you have me do, my land is gone,
My credit of less trust than Courtiers words
To men of judgment, and for my debts
I might deserve a Knight-hood; what is to be done?
The Knight my father will not once vouchsafe
To call me son; That little land he gave;
Throte the Lawyer swallowed at one gob,
For less than half the worth, and for the City
There be so many rascals, and tall yeomen
Would hang upon me for their maintenance,
Should I but peep or step within the gates,
That I am forced only to ease my charge,
To live here in the suburbs: or in the town
To walk in Tenebris, I tell you sir,
Your best retired life is an honest Punk
In a thatched house with Garlic: tell not me,
My Punk is my Punk, and noble Lechery
Sticks by a man, when all his friends forsake him.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: The Pox it will, art thou so senseless grown,
So much endeared to thy bestial lust,
That thy original worth should lie extinct
And buried in thy shame? far be such thoughts
From spirits free and noble: begin to live,
Know thyself, and whence thou art derived,
I know that competent state thy father gave,
Cannot be yet consumed.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: It is gone by Heaven,
Not a denier is left.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Impossible zart I have had two suckers,
Able to spend the wealthy Cræsus store.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why a Lawyer and a Whore,
See here comes one, doest think this petticoat,
A perfumed smock, and twice a week a bathe,
Can be maintained with half a years revenues,
No by Heaven, we Annual younger brothers,
Must go to it by hole-sale, by hole-sale man
These creatures are maintained: her very face
Has cost a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, thank yourself.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: They keep this whore betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You know sir,
I did enjoy a quiet country life,
Spotless and free, till you corrupted me,
And brought me to the Court, I never knew,
What sleeking, glazing, or what pressing meant,
Till you preferred me to your Aunt the Lady,
I knew no Ivory teeth, no caps of heir,
No Mercury water, fucas, or perfumes,
To help a Ladies breath, until your Aunt,
Learnt me the common trick.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: The common trick,
Say you, a pox upon such common tricks,
They will undo us all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: And knowing this
Art thou so wilful blind, still to persist
In ruin and defame.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What should I do?
I have past my word to keep this Gentlewoman,
Till I can place her to her own content,
And what is a Gentleman but his word.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Why let her go to service.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: To service,
Why so she does, she is my Laundress,
And by this light, no puny Inn a Court
But keeps a Laundress at his command
To do him service, and shall not I, ha!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, you are his friend (I love him too)
Propound a course which may advantage him,
And you shall find such real worth in me,
That rather than I will live his hindrance,
I will assume the most penurious state
The City yields, to give me means of life.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why there is it, you hear her what she says,
Would not he be damned that should forsake her,
Says she not well, can you propound a course,
To get my forfeit land, from yonder rogue,
Parcel Lawyer, parcel Devil, all Knave,
Thrate, throate.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why so, I thought as much,
You are like our Citizens to men in need,
Which cry it is pity, a proper Gentleman,
Should want money, yet not an usuring slave,
Will lend him a denier, to help his wants,
Will you lend me forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why God-a-mercy, there is some goodness in thee,
You will not repent.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: VV. S.
sp.l: With that money
I will redeem my forfeit land, and wed
My Cockatrice to a man of worship,
To a man of worship by this light.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: But how?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Thus in Ram-alley lies a fellow, by name
Throte: one that professeth law, but indeed
Has neither law nor conscience, a fellow
That never saw the bar, but when his life
Was called in question for a cozenage,
The Rogue is rich, to him go you, tell him
That rich Sir Iohn Somerfield.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Is lately dead, and that my hopes stand fair
To get his only daughter. If I speed,
And have but means to steal away the wench,
Tell him I reckon him my chiefest friend,
To entertain us till our nuptial rites
May be accomplished, and could you but procure
My elder brother meet me on the way,
And but associate me unto his house,
It were hit i'faith, I would give my cunning Throte
An honest slit for all his tricks in law.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Why this shall be performed, take there is my store,
To friends all things are common.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Then at the court
There are none foes, for all things there are common.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will as carefully perform thy wish,
As if my fortunes lay upon the attempt.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: When shall I hear from you.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Within this hour

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Let me alone for the rest, if I gull not
And go beyond my open throated lawyer,
For all his book cases of Tricesimo nono
And Quadragessimo octauo: let me
Like waiting Gentlewomen be ever bound,
To sit upon my heels, and pick rushes,
Will you about this gear.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: With my best speed.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Then fare you well, you will meet me.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Without fail.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Adieu: now you pernicious Cockatrice,
You see how I must skelder for your good,
I will bring you where you shall have means to cheat,
If you have grace enough to apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Believe me love, how ever some stricter wits,
Condemn all women which are prone to love,
And think that if their favour fall on any,
By consequence they must be naught with many,
And hold a false position, that a woman
False to herself, can trusty be to no man,
Yet know I say, how ever my life hath lost
The fame which my Virginity aspired,
I will be true to thee, my deed shall move,
To win from all men pity, if not love.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Tut, I know thee a good rascal, let us in,
And on with all your neat and finest rags.
On with your cloak and safe-guard, you arrant drab,
You must cheat without all conscience, filch for thee and me.
Do but thou act what I shall well contrive,
We will teach my Lawyer a new way to thrive.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Mistresse Tafata, and Adriana her maid aboue.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come loved Adriana here let us sit,
And mark who passes; now for a wager,
What coloured beard comes next by the window?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A black man's I think.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I think not so,
I think a read, for that is most in fashion,
Lord how scarce is the world of proper men
And gallants; sure we never more shall see
A good leg worn in a long silk stocking,
With a long codpiece, of all fashions
That carried it i'faith, what is he goes by?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A snivelling Citizen, he is carrying ware,
Unto some Ladies chamber: but who is this?

div2.stage: Enter T. Smal-shanke reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I know him not, he looks just like a fool.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He is very brave he may be a Courtier,
What is that he reads.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Ah how light he treads
For dirtying his silk stockings, I will tell thee what,
A witty woman may with ease distinguish,
All men by their noses, as thus: your nose
Tuscan is lovely, large and broad,
Much like a Goose, your valiant generous nose.
A crooked smooth and a great puffing nose,
Your scholars nose is very fresh and raw
For want of fire in winter, and quickly smells,
His chops of mutton, in his dish of porridge.
Your Puritan nose is very sharpe and long,
And much like your widows, and with ease can smell,
An edifying capon some five streets off,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O mistress a very proper gentleman,

sp.speaker: Tafa.
sp.l: And trust me so it is, I never saw
A man that sooner could captive my thoughts
(Since I writ widow) than this gentleman,
I would he would look up.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I will laugh so loud
That he may hear me.

sp.speaker: Tafa.
sp.l: That is not so good

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: And spake you with Master Smalshanke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Will he meet his brother.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He said he would,
And I believed him, I tell you master
I have done that for many of these gallants
That no man in this town would do but I.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What is is that boy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why trust them on their words
But will you hear the news which now supplies,
The city with discourse.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What is it wag

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This sir, they say some of our city dames
Were much desirous to see the Baboons
Do their newest tricks, went, saw them, came home,
Went to bed, slept, next morning one of them,
Being to shift a smock, sends down her maid,
To warm her one, mean while she gins to think
On the Baboons tricks, and naked in her bed
Begins to practise some, at last she strove,
To get her right leg over her head; thus:
And by her activity she got it
Cross the shoulder: but not withal her power,
Could she reduce it, at last much struggling
Tumbles quite from the bed upon the flower,
The maid by this returned with the warm smock,
And seeing her mistress thrown on the ground
Trust up like a football, exclaims, calls help,
Runs down amazed, swears that her mistress neck
Is broke up comes her husband and neighbours,
And finding her thus trussed, some flatly said
She was bewitch, others she was possessed,
A third said for her pride, the Devil had set
Her face where her rump should stand, but at last
Her valiant husband steppes me boldly to her,
Helps her; she ashamed; her husband amazed,
The neighbours laughing as none forbear,
She tells them of the fatal accident.
To which one answers, that if her husband
Would leave his trade, and carry his wife about
To do this trick in public, she would get more gold
Than all the Baboons, Calves with two tails,
Or motions whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You are a wag,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: He will be gone if we neglect to stay him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Shall I cough or sneeze.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: No I have it stand a side,
Aye me my handkercher Adriand, Fabia.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Mistress,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Run, run I have let my handkercher fall,
Gentleman shall I entreat a courtesy,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Within my power your beauty shall command.
What courtesy is it.

sp.speaker: Tas.
sp.l: To stoop and take up,
My handkercher.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Your desire is performed.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir most hearty thanks: please you come in
Your welcome shall transcend your expectation.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I accept your courtesy, ha! what is this?
Assailed by fear and hope in a moment.
Boucher this womanish passion fits not men,
Who know the worth of freedom: shall smiles and eyes
With their lascivious glances conquer him
Hath still been Lord of his affections?
Shall simpering niceness load-stones but to fools,
Attract a knowing spirit: it shall, it does,
Not Phœbus rising from Auroras lap,
Spreads his bright rays with more majestic grace
Then came the glances from her quickening eye
And what of this.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: By my troth I know not

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will not enter: continued flames burn strong,
I yet am free and reason keeps her seat,
Above all fond affections yet is she fair.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Sir I bring you thanks for this great courtesy,
And if you please to enter I dare presume,
My mistress will afford you gracious welcome,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How do men call your mistress.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The man is in love.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Her name sir is Mistress Changeable, late wife
To master Tafata Mercer deceased.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.l: I have heard she is both rich and beautiful,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: In the eyes of such as love her, judge yourself.
Please you but prick forward and enter,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now will I fall a board the watiing maid,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Fall a board of me, dost take me for a ship,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I And will shoot you betwixt wind and water.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Blurt master gunner your linstock too short.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Foot how did she know that, dost hear sweet heart
Should not the page be doing with the maid,
Whilst the master is busy with the mistress,
Please you prick forwards, thou art a wench
Likely to go the way of all flesh shortly

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Whose witty knave art thou.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: At your service.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: At mine faith, I should breach thee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How breach me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I breach thee, I have breach a taller man,
Than you in my time, come in and welcome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well I see now a rich well-practised bawd,
May purse more fees in a summers progress,
Than a well traded lawyer in a whole term,
Panderism! why it is grown a liberal science
Or a new sect, and the good professors
Will like the Brownest frequent gravel pits shortly,
For they use woods and obscure holes already.
Not marry a widow.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And why?
Belike you think it base and servant-like,
To feed upon reversion, you hold us widows,
But as a pie thrust to the lower end
That hath had many fingers in it before,
And is reserved for gross and hungry stomachs.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You much mistake me.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Come in faith you do:
And let me tell you that is but ceremony,
For though the Pie be broken up before,
Yet says the proverb, the deeper is the sweeter.
And though a capons wings and legs be carved,
The flesh left with the rump I hope is sweet.
I tell you sir, I have been wooed, and sued too,
By worthy Knights of fair demeans: nay more,
They have been out of debt, yet till this hour,
I neither could endure, to be in love.
Or be beloved, but proffered ware is cheap.
what is lawful that is loathed, and things denied,
Are with more stronger appetite pursued.
I am to yielding.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You mistake my thoughts.
But know thou wonder of this continent,
By one more skilled in unknown fate, than was,
The blind Achaian Prophet, It was foretold,
A widow should endanger both my life,
My soul, my lands, and reputation,
This checks my thoughts, and cools the essential fire,
Of sacred love; more ardent in my breast
Than speech can utter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: A trivial Idle jest,
It is for a man, of your repute, and note,
To credit fortunetellers, a petty rogue,
That never saw five shillings, in a heap
Will take upon him to divine men's fate,
Yet never knows himself, shall die a beggar,
Or be hanged up for pilfering table clothes,
Shirts and smocks, hanged out to dry on hedges,
It is merely base, to trust them, or if there be,
A man in whom the Delphic, God hath breathed,
His true divining fire, that can foretell,
The fixed decree of fate, he likewise knows,
What is within the everlasting book,
Of Destiny decreed cannot by wit,
Or man's Invention be dissolved, or shunned,
Then give thy love free scope embrace and kiss,
And to the distaff sisters leave the event,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How powerful are their words whom we affect,
Small force shall need, to win the strongest fort,
If to his state the Captain be perfidious,
I must entreat you licence my depart
For some few hours.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Choose what you will of time,
There lies your way.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will entreat her, stay.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Did you call sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Then fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Who gins to love, needs not a second Hell.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Adriana, makes he no stay.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I prithee see if he have left the house,
Peep close, see, but be not seen: is he gone.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: No, has made a stand.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I prithee keep close.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Nay, keep you close you had best.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Now he retires.

sp.speaker: Bou,
sp.l: O you much partial gods!
Why gave you men affections, and not a power
To govern them? what I by fate should shun,
I most affect, a widow, a widow.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Blows the wind there.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A ha, he is in i'faith,
You have drawn him now within your purlieus mistress.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Tut I will not love, my rational
And better parts shall conquer blind affections,
Let passion children, or weak women sway,
My love shall to my judgment still obey.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What does he now?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He is gone.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Gone Adriana,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He went his way, and never looked behind him.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sure he is taken.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A little singed or so,
Each thing must have beginning, men must prepare
Before they can come on, and show their loves
In pleasing sort: the man will do in time,
For love good Mistress is much like to wax,
The more it is rubbed, it sticks the faster too,
Or like a bird in bird-lime, or a pit-fall,
The more he labours, still the deeper in.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come, thou must help me now, I have a trick
To second this beginning, and in the nick,
To strike it dead i'faith, women must woe,
When men forget what Nature leads them to.

div2.stage: Enter Throte the Lawyer from his study bookes and bags of money on a Table, a chaire and cushion.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Chaste Phoebe, splende; there is that left yet,
Next to my book, Claro micante Auro,
Aye that is the soul of law: that is it, that is it,
For which the Buckram bag must trudge all weathers:
Though scarcely filled with one poor replication,
How happy are we that we joy the law,
So freely as we do; not bought and sold,
But clearly given, without all base extorting,
Taking but bare ten Angels for a fee,
Or upward: to this renowned estate,
Have I by indirect and cunning means,
In-wouen myself, and now can scratch it out,
Thrust at a bar, and cry my Lord as loud,
As ever listed gowne-man of them all.
I never plead before the honoured bench,
But bench right-worshipful of peaceful Justices
And Country-Gentlemen, and yet I have found
Good gettings by the Mass, besides odd cheats,
Will Small-shankes lands and many garboils more,

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: Dash Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is that reindeer done.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Done sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Have you drawn it at length, have you dashed it out,
According to your name.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Some seven-score sheets.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is the demurrer drawn betwixt Snip and Woodcock,
And what do you say to Peacocks pitiful bill,

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: I have drawn his answer negative to all.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Negative to all. The plaintive says,
That William Goose, was son to Thomas Goose,
And will he swear the general bill is false.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: He will.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then he forswears his father, it is well,
Some of our clients will go prig to hell
Before ourselves; has he paid all his fees.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: He left them all with me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then truss my points,
And how thinkst thou of law?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Most reverently,
Law is the worlds great light, a second sun,
To this terrestrial Globe, by which all things
Have life and being, and with-out which
Confusion and disorder soon would seize
The general state of men, wars, outrages,
The ulcerous deeds of peace, it curbs and cures,
It is the kingdoms eye, by which she sees
The acts and thoughts of men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The kingdoms eye,
I tell thee fool, it is the kingdoms nose,
By which she smells out all these rich transgressors,
Nor is it of flesh but merely made of wax,
And it is, within the power of us Lawyers,
To wrest this nose of wax which way we please.
Or it may be as thou sayst an eye indeed.
But if it be it is sure a woman's eye
That is ever rolling.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: one knocks.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go see who it is,
Stay, my chair, and gown, and then go see who knocks.
Thus must I seem a Lawyer which am indeed,
But merely dregs and off scum of the Law,
It is very clear.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The place is very pregnant, Master Boucher;
Most hearty welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You study hard,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: No I have a cushion.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You ply this gear,
You are no truant in the law, I see.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some hundred books in folio I have
Turned over to better my own knowledge,
But that is nothing for a studient,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Or a Stationer they turn them over too,
But not as you do gentle Master Throat,
And what? the Law speaks profit does it not?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some bad angels haunt us now and then,
But what brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Why these smale legs,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You are conceited sir,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I am in Law.
But let that go, and tell me how you do,
How does Will Smalshankes and his lovely bride,

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: In troth you make me blush, I should have asked,
His health of you, but it is not yet too late.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Nay good sir Throat forbear your quillets now,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By Heaven I deal most plain, I saw him not,
Since last I took his Mortgage.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Sir be not nice,
(Yet I must needs herein commend your love)
To let me see him; for know I know him wed,
And that he stole away Sommerfields heir,
Therefore suspect me not I am his friend,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: How wed to rich Sommerfields only heir,
Is old Sommerfield dead?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Do you make it strange?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By heaven I know it nor.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Then am I grieved.
I spake so much (but that I know you love him.
And is reserved for gross and hungry stomachs.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You much mistake me.
I should entreat your secrecy sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: Nay good sir stay, if aught you can disclose
Of Master Smale-shankes good, let me partake,
And make me glad in knowing his good hap.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You much endear him sir, and from your love,
I dare presume you make yourself a fortune
If his fair hopes proceed.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Say on good sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You will be secret.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Or be my tongue torn out.

sp.speaker: Bouch.
sp.l: Measure for a Lawyer, but to the point
Has stole Somerfields heir hither he brings her
As to a man on whom a may rely
His life and fortunes: you hath he named
Already for the Steward of his lands,
To keep his Courts, and to collect his rent,
To let out Leases and to raise his fines,
Nothing that may, or love, or profit bring,
But you are named the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am his slave
And bound unto his noble courtesy -
Even with my life, I ever said he would thrive,
And I protest I kept his forfeit mortgage,
To let him know what it is to live in want.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.l: I think no less, one word more in private.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Good Master Dash shall I put you now a case.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: Speak on good Master Page.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then thus it is,
Suppose I am a Page, he is my Master,
My Master goes to bed and cannot tell
What money is in his hose, I ere next day
Have filched out some, what action lies for this.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: An action boy, called firking the Posteriors,
With us your action seldom comes in question:
For that it is known that most of your Gallants
Are seldom so well stored, that they forget
What money is in their hose, but if they have,
There is no other help than swear the page
And put him to his oath.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Then fecks-law,
Dost think that he has conscience to steal,
Has not he conscience likewise to deny.
Then hang him up i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I must meet him,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Commend me to them, come when they will,
My doors stand open and all within is theirs
And though Ram stinks with Cooks and ale,
Yet say there is many a worthy lawyers chamber,
Buts upon Ram-Alley, I have still an open throte,
If aught I have which may procure his good,
Bid him command, Aye, though it be my blood.

div2.stage: Actus Secundi. Scena Prima. Enter Oliuer Smaleshanke, Thomas Smale Shanke.

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.p: Is this the place you were appointed to meet him.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: I find it true,
That wine, good news, and a young wholesome wench
Cheer up an old man's blood, I tell thee boy,
I am right hearty glad, to hear thy brother;
Hath got so great an heir; now were myself,
So well bestowed I should rejoice i'faith.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: I hope you shall do well.

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt.
A sirrah has he borne the wench away,
My son i'faith, my very son i'faith,
When I was young and had an able back,
And wore the bristles on my upper lip,
In good Decorum I had as good conveyance,
And could have ferd, and ferkt you away a wench,
As soon as ear a man a live; tut boy,
I had my winks, my becks treads on the toe,
Wrings by the fingers, smiles and other quirks,
No Courtier like me, your Courtiers all are fools,
To that which I could do, I could have done it boy.
Even to a hare, and that some Ladies know,

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Sir I am glad this match may reconcile,
Your love unto my brother.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: It is more than so.
I will seem offended still though I am glad,
sp.stage: Enter Willian Smals-shanke Francis, Beard booted.
sp.l: Has got rich Sommer-fields heir.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Come wench of gold,
For thou shalt get me gold, besides odd ends
Of silver: we will purchase house and land,
By thy bare gettings, wench, by thy bare gettings,
How sayst lieutenantship, does she not look
Like a wench newly stole from a window?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Exceeding well she carries it by Jove;
And if she can forbear her Rampant trick,
And but hold close a while it will take by Mars.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How now you slave? my rampant tricks you rogue,
Nay fear not me my only fear is still,
Thy filthy face betrays us, for all men know,
Thy nose stands compass like a bow,
Which is three quarters drawn, thy head.
Which is with greasy hair overspread,
And being uncurled and black as cole,
Doth show some Scullion in a hole
Be got thee on a Gypsy, or
Thy mother was some Colliers whore
My rampant tricks you rogue, thou wilt be descried
Before our plot be ended.

sp.speaker: W, S.
sp.l: What should descry him,
Unless it be his nose? and as for that;
Thou mayst protest he was thy fathers butler,
And for thy love is likewise run away,
Nay sweet Lieutenant now forbear to puff,
And let the bristles of thy beard grow downward,
Reverence my Punk and Pandarize a little,
There is many of thy rank that do profess it,
Yet hold it no disparagement.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall do,
What fits an honest man.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why that is enough,
Foot my Father and the goose my brother,
Back you two.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Back.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Retire sweet Lieutenant,
And come not on, till I shall wave you on.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: Is not that he.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: It is he.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: wheres the wench.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: It shall be so, I will cheat him that is flat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You are well met, know ye me good sir,
Belike you think I have no eyes, no ears,
No nose to smell, and wind out all your tricks,
You have stole Sir Somerfields heir, nay we can find,
Your wildest paths, your turnings and returns,
Your traces, squats, the insets, forms and holes,
You young men use, if once cursagest wits
Be set a hunting, are you now crept forth,
Have you hid your head within a suburb hole
All this while, and are you now crept forth?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: It is a stark lie.

sp.speaker: Sir. Ol.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: who told you so did lie,
Foot, a Gentleman cannot leave the City
And keep the suburbs to take a little Physic,
But straight some slave will say he hides his head:
I hide my head within a Suburb hole,
I could have holes at Court to hide my head,
Were I but so disposed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Thou varlet knave,
Thou hast stolen away Sir Iohn Somerfields heir,
But never look for countenance from me,
Carry her whether thou wilt.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Father, father,
Zart will you undo your posterity.
Will you sir undo your posterity?
I can but kill my brother then hang myself,
And where is then your house, make me not despair,
Foot now I have got a wench, worth by the year
Two thousand pound and upwards, to cross my hopes:
Would ever a clown in Christendom do it but you.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Good Father, let him leave this thundering,
And give him grace.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why law, my brother knows
Reason, and what an honest man should do.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Well, wheres your wife.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: She is coming here behind,

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I will give her some-what, though I love not thee.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: My father right, I knew you could not hold
Out long with a woman, but give some-thing
Worthy your gift and her acceptance father,
This chain were excellent by this good-light,
She shall give you as good if once her lands
Come to my fingering.

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: Peace knave, what is she your wife?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: That shall be sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: And what is he.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: My man.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: A Ruffian Knave he is.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: A Ruffian sir,
By heaven, as tall a man as ever drew sword,
Not being counted of the damned crew,
He was her fathers Butler, his name is Beard,
Of with your Mask, now shall you find me true,
And that I am a son unto a Knight,
This is my father.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I am indeed fair maid,
My style is Knight: come let me kiss your lips.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: That kiss shall cost your chain.

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: It smacks i'faith,
I must commend your choice.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir I have given
A longer venture than true modesty
Will well allow, or your more graver wit
Commend.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I dare be sworn she has.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not so,
The foolish knave has been accounted wild,
And so have I, but I am now come home,
And so will he.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I must believe it now.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Beg his chain wench.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Will you cheat your father?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Aye by this light will I.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay sigh not.
For you shall find him loving and me thankful.
And were it not a scandal to my honour,
To be consenting to my sons attempt,
You should unto my house, mean while take this,
As pledge and token of my after love:
How long since died your father.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Some six weeks since.
We cannot stay to talk, for slaves pursue,
I have a house shall lodge us till the Priest
May make us sure.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Well sirrah, love this woman,
And when you are man and wife bring her to me,
She shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I humbly thank you sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I must be gone, I must a wooing too.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Jove and Priapus speed you, you will return.

div2.stage: Exit Sir Oliuer and Thom: Small-shanke.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Instantly.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why this came cleanly off,
Give me the chain, you little Cockatrice,
Why this was luck, foot four hundred crowns
Got at a clap, hold still your own you whore,
And we shall thrive.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: It was bravely fetched about.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Aye, when will your nose and beard perform as much.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am glad he is gone, he put me to the blush
When he did ask me of rich Somerfields death.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: And took not I my cue wast not good,
Did I not bring you off, you arrant drab,
Without a counterbuff? look who comes here,
And three merry men, and three merry men,
And three merry men be we a.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Still in this vain, I have done you service,
The Lawyers house will give you entertainment,
Bountiful and free.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: O my second self,
Come let me buss thy beard, we are all made,
Why art so melancholy, doest want money?
Look here is gold, and as we pass along,
I will tell thee how I got it, not a word
But that she is Somerfields heir, my brother
Swallows it with more ease, than a Dutchman
Does slap-Dragons: he comes, now to my Lawyers:
Kiss my wife, good brother; she is a wench
Was born to make us all.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: I hope no less,
You are welcome sister into these our parts,
As I may say.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thanks gentle brother.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Come now to Ram-alley. There shalt thou lie,
Till I provide a Priest.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: O villainy!
I think he will gull his whole generation,
I must make one, since it is so well begun,
I will not forsake him, till his hopes be won.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Throate, and two Cittizens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then you are friends.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We are, so please your worship.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: It is well, I am glad, keep your money, for law
Is like a Butlers box: while you two strive,
That picks up all your money, you are friends,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We are so please you, both perfect friends.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Why so,
Now to the next Tap-house, there drink down this,
And by the operation of the third pot.
Quarrel again, and come to me for law:
Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: The Gods concern your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why so, these are tricks of the long fifteens,
To give counsel, and to take fees on both sides,
To make them friends, and then to laugh at them,
Why this thrives well, this is a common trick:
When men have spent a deal of money in law,
Then Lawyers make them friends: I have a trick
To go beyond all these, if Small-shanke come
And bring rich Somerfields heir, I say no more,
But it is within this sconce to go beyond them.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Here are Gentlemen in haste would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: I cannot know them sir
They are so wrapped in Cloaks.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Have they a woman?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Yes sir, but she is Masked, and in her riding suit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go, make haste, bring them up with reverence,
O are they i'faith, has brought the wealthy heir:
These stools and cushions stand not handsomely.

div2.stage: Enter William Smalshanke, Boutcher. Thomas Smalshanke, Francis, and Beard.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Bless thee Throte.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Master Smalshanke welcome.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Welcome love, kiss this Gentlewoman, Throte.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Your worship shall command me.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Art not weary.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Can you blame her since she has rid so hard?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You are welcome Gentlemen.---Dash.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: A fire in the great chamber, quickly.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Aye that is well said, we are almost weary,
But Master Throte, if any come to inquire
For me, my brother, or this Gentlewoman,
We are not here, nor have you heard of us.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Not a word sir, here you are as safe
As in your fathers house,

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: And he shall thank you.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Thou art not merry love, good master Throte
Bid this Gentlewoman welcome: she is one
Of whom you may receive some courtesy
In time.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: She is most hearty welcome,
Wilt please you walk into another room,
Where is both bed and fire.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Aye, aye, that that
Good brother lead her in, Master Throte and I
Will follow instantly, now Master Throte
It rests within your power to pleasure me,
Know that this same is sir Iohn Somerfields Heir,
Now if she chance to question what I am,
Say son unto a Lord, I pray thee tell her
I have a world of land, and stand in hope
To be created Baron, for I protest
I was constrained to swear it forty times
And yet she will scarce believe me.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: pauca sapienti,
Let me alone to set you out in length
And breadth:

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: I prithee do it effectually:
Shat have a quarter share by this good light,
In all she has, I prithee forget not
To tell her the Smal-shankes have been dancers,
Tilters, and very ancient Courtiers,
And in request at Court since sir Iohn Short-hose
With his long silk stockings was beheaded,
Wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: Refer it to my care.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Excellent, I will but shift my boots, and then
Go seek a Priest, this night I will be sure,
If we be sure, it cannot be undone,
Can it Master Throte?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O sir not possible:
You have many Presidents and book Cases for it,
Be you but sure and then let me alone.
Viuat Rex, currat Lex and I will defend you.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Nay then hang care, come let us in.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: A ha,
Have you stole her, fallere fallentem non est fraus.
It shall go hard but I will strip you boy.
You stole the wench, but I must her enjoy.

div2.stage: Exit Enter Mistris Taffata, Adriana, below.

sp.l: Come Adriana, tell me what thou thinkst,
I am tickled with conceit of marriage,
And whom thinkst thou (for me) the fittest husband
What sayst thou to young Bouchor.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: A pretty fellow
But that his back is weak,

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: What dost thou say
To Throte the Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: I like that well,
Were the Rogue a Lawyer, but he is none,
He never was of any Inne-of-court;
But Inn of Chancery, where he was known,
But only for a swaggering whiffler,
To keep out rogues, and prentices, I saw him,
When a was stocked for stealing the cooks fees.
A Lawyer I could like, for it is a thing,
Used by you Citizens wives, your husbands dead;
To get French-hoods you straight must Lawyers wed,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What sayst thou then to Nimble Sir Oliu, Smal-shanck

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Faith he must hit the hair: a fellow fit,
To make a pretty Cuckold: take an old man,
It is now the newest fashion, better be
An old man's darling, than a young man's warling,
Take me the old brisk Knight, the fool is rich,
And will be strong enough to father children,
Though, not to get them.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: It is true he is the man,
Yet will I bear some dozen more in hand,
And make them all my gulls.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Mistress stand aside.
Young Boutcher comes let me alone to touch him.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: This is the house.
And that is the chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Where is the widow gentle Adriana.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The widow sir is not to be spoken to,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Not speak to, I must speak with her.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Must you!
Come you with authority, or do you come
To sue her with a warrant that you must speak with her.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I would Entreat it.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O you would entreat it,
May not I serve your turn, may not I unfold,
Your secrets to my Mistress, love is your suit,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: It is fair creature.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: And why did you fall off
When you perceived my mistress was so cunning,
Do you think she is still the same.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why so,
I took you for a novice; and I must think,
You know not yet the inwards of a woman,
Do you not know that women are like fish,
Which must be struck when they are prone to byte,
Or all your labours lost, but sir walk here.
And I will inform my Mistress your desires.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: boy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: come not you for love,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I do boy

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And you would have ye widow.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I would

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I never saw one go about his business
More untowardly: why sir, do not you know
That he which would be inward with the Mistress,
Must make a way first through the waiting maid?
If you will know the widows affections
Feel first the waiting Gentle-woman; do it Master,
Some half a dozen kisses were not lost
Upon this Gentle-woman, for you must know
These waiting-maids are to their Mistresses
Like Porches unto doors, you pass the one
Before you can have entrance at the other:
Or like your mustered to your piece of brawn,
If you will have one taste well you must not scorn
To be dipping in the other, I tell you Master
It is not a few men's tales which they prefer
Unto their Mistress, in compass of a yeare---
Be ruled by me, untruss yourself to her,
Out with all your love-sick thoughts to her,
Kiss her and give her an angel to buy pins,
And this shall sooner win her Mistress love,
Than all your protestations, sighs and tears.
Here they come; to her boldly Master
Do, but dally not, that is the widows phrase,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Most worthy fair such is the power of love
That now I come to accept your proffered grace,
And with submissive thoughts to entreat a pardon
For my so gross neglect.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: There is no offence,
My mind is changed.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I told you as much before.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With a hey pass with a repass.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Dearest of women,
The constant virtue of your nobler mind
Speaks in your looks: Nor can you entertain
Both love and hate at once.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: It is all in vain.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: You strive against the stream.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Fee the waiting maid Master

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Stand thou propitious, endear me to thy love

div2.stage: Boutcher giues Adriana his purse secretly.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Dear Mistress turn to this Gentleman, I protest,
I have some feeling of his constant love,
Cast him not away, try his love.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Why sir,
With what audacious front can you entreat
To enjoy my love, which yet not two hours since,
You scornfully refused.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well sare the waiting maid.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: My fate compelled me, but now farewell fond fear,
My soul, my life, my lands, and reputation,
I will hazard all, and prize them all beneath thee.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Which I shall put to trial, lend me thy ear.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Can you love boy.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: What or whom.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: My victuals.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A pretty knave, i'faith come home tonight,
Shalt have a posset and candied Eringoes,
A bed if need be too, I love a life,
To play with such Baboons as thou.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Indeed,
But doest think the widow will have my master.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I will tell thee then, won't come.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Remember.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Will you perform so much.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Or lose my blood.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Make him subscribe it, and then I vow,
By sacred Uestaes ever hallowed fire,
To take thee to my bed.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Till when farewell.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: He is worthy love, whose virtues most excel.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Remember, what is it a match betwixt you Mistress?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I have set the fool in hope, he has undertook
To rid me of that fleshly Captain Face,
Which swears in Taverns, and all Ordinaries,
I am his lawful wife: he shall allay,
The fury of the Captain, and I secure,
Will laugh at the disgrace they both endure.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Open your case, and I shall soon resolve you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But will you do it truly.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: As I am honest.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This Gentleman whom I so much affect,
I scarcely yet do know, so blind is love,
In things which most concerns it, as you are honest
Tell me his birth, his state, and farthest hopes.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: He is my friend, and I will speak him truly,
He is by birth, son to a foolish Knight,
His present state I think will be the prison,
And farthest hope to be bailed out again,
By sale of all your land.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O me accursed,
Has he no credit, Lands and Manors.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: That lands he has lies in a fair Church-yard,
And for his manners, they are so rude and vile,
That scarce an honest man will keep him company.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am abused, cozened, and deceived.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why that is his occupation, he will cheat
In a cloak lined with Velvet, he will prate
Faster than five Barbers and a Taylor,
Lie faster than ten City occupiers,
Or cunning tradesmen: goes a trust
In every Tavern where has spent a faggot,
Swears love to every whore, squires bawds,
And takes up houses for them as their husband.
He is a man I love, and have done much
To bring him to preferment.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is there no trust,
No honesty in men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some there is,
And it is all in the hands of us Lawyers
And women, and those women which have it,
Keep their honesty so close, that not one
Amongst a hundred is perceived to have it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good sir, may I not by law forsake him
And wed another, though my word be past
To be his wife.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O questionless you may,
You have many Presidents and book-cases for it,
Nay, though you were married by a bookcases,
Of Milesimo sexantesimo, etcetera.
You may forsake your husband, and wed another,
Provided that some fault be in the husband,
As none of them are clear.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am resolved,
I will not wed him, though I beg my bread.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: All that I have is yours, and were I worthy
To be your husband.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
I will rather wed a most perfidious Redshanke,
A noted Jew, or some Mechanic slave,
Than let him joy my sheets.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: He comes, he comes,

div2.stage: Enter W. Smal. Boutcher, T. Smal. Beard.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Now my Virago, it is done, all is cock-sure,
I have a Priest will mumble up a marriage,
Without bell, book, or candle, a nimble slave,
A honest Welsh-man that was a Taylor,
But now is made a Curate.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Nay you are fitted.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Now master Throte.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Where is your spirit sister?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What all amort? what is the matter? do you hear?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What is the reason of this melancholy?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By heaven I know not.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Has the gudgeon bit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He has been nibbling.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Hold him to it wench,
And it it will hit by heaven: why art so sad?
Foot wench we will be married tonight,
We will sup at the Miter, and from thence
My brother and we three will to the Savoy,
Which done, I tell thee girl, we will hand over head,
Go to it pell mell for a maiden-head,
Come you are lusty, you wenches are like bells,
You give no music, till you feel the clapper,
Come Throte a torch, we must be gone.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Servant.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: We are undone.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Now Jove forfend.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This fellow has no land; and which is worse,
He has no credit.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.l: How are we outstripped,
Blown up by wit of man: Let us be gone
Home again, home again, our market now is done.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That were too great a scandal.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Most true,
Better to wed another, than to return
With scandal and defame: wed me a man
Whose wealth may reconcile your mothers love,
And make the action lawful.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But where is the man?
I like your council, could you show the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Myself am he, might I but dare aspire
Unto so high a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Mistress, take the man,
Shall we be baffled with fair promises,
Or shall we trudge, like beggars back again,
No, take this wise and virtuous man,
Who should he lose his legs, his arms, his ears,
His nose, and all his other members,
Yer if his tongue be left it will get his living,
Take me this man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Thanks gentle master Beard.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is impossible, this night he means to wed me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: If not by law, we will with power prevent it,
So you but give consent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Let us hear the means.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I will muster up my friends, and thus I cast it,
Whilst they are busy, you and I will hence
Directly to a Chapel, where a Priest
Shall knit the nuptial knot ere they pursue us.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O rare invention, I will act my part,
He owes me thirteen pound, I say no more,
But there be catch-poles: speak is it a match.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I give my liking.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dash.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Get your sword
And me my buckler, nay you shall know
We are Tam marti quam mercurio,
Bring my cloak, you shall thither, I will for friends,
Worship and wealth the Lawyers state attends.
Dash, we must bear some brain, to Saint Iohns street,
Go run, fly: and a far off enquire,
If that the Lady Somerfield be there,
If there, know what news, and meet me straight
At the Myter door in Fleet-street, away,
To get rich wives, men must not use delay.

div2.stage: Actus 3. Scæna 1. Enter Sir Oliuer Smalshanke, Iustice Tutchim.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.p: A hunting Sir Oliuer and dry foot too,

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: We old men have our crotchets, our conundrums,
Our fegares, quirks and quibibles,
As well as youth, Justice Tutchim I go
To hunt no Buck, but prick a lusty Do,
I go in truth a wooing.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Then ride with me,
I will bring you to my sister Somerfield.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Justice not so: by her there hangs a Tale.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: That is true indeed.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: She has a daughter.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: And what of that.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I likewise have a son,
A villainous Boy, his father up and down,
What should I say, these Velvet bearded boys,
Will still be doing, say what we old men can,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: And what of this Sir Oliuer, be plain,

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.l: A nimble spirited knave, the villain boy,
Has one trick of his sire, has got the wench.
Stolen your rich Sisters heir.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Somer-fields heir,

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Has done the deed, has pierced the vessels head,
And knows by this the vintage.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: when should this be,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: As I am by my council well informed,
This very day,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Tut It cannot be,
Some ten miles hence I saw the maid last night.

sp.speaker: S. Ol,
sp.l: Maids may be maids tonight and not tomorrow.
Women are free and sell their maiden-heads,
As men sell cloth, by yard and handful,
But if you chance to see your Sister widow,
Comfort her tears and say her daughters matched,
With one that has a knocker to his Father,
An honest Noble Knight.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Stand close Knight, close,
And mark this Captains humour, his name is Puff,
He dreams as he walks, and thinks no woman
Sees him but is in love with him.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: It were brave,
If some great Lady, through a window spied me,
And straight should love me, say she should send,
5000. pound unto my Lodging,
And crave my company: with that money,
I would make three several cloaks, and line them
With black, Crimson, and Tawny three piled velvet,
I would eat at Chares Ordinary, and dice
At Antonies: then would I keep my whore,
In beaten velvet and, have two slaves to tend her.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: What my case of Justices,
What are you eaves-dropping or do you think,
Your tawny coats with greasy facings here,
Shall carry it? Sir Oliuer Smal-shankes,
Know my name is Puff, Knight, thee have I sought,
To fright thee from thy wits.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Puff,
We have too many mad men already.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How? I tell thee Justice Tuchim, not all
Thy Bailiffs, Sergeants busy Constables,
Defesants, warrants, or thy Mittimusses,
Shall save his throte from cutting if he presume,
To woe the widow yclept Tafata,
She is my wife by oath. Therefore take heed,
Let me not catch thee in the widows house,
If I do, I will pick thy head upon my sword,
And piss in thy very physiognomy, beware, beware.
Come there no more, a Captains word,
Flies not so fierce as doth his fatal sword,

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: How like you this, shall we endure this thunder,
Or go no further.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: We will on Sir Oliuer,
We will on, let me aloue to touch him,
I wounder how my spirit did forbear,
To strike him on the face: had this been spoke,
Within my Liberties, had died for it.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: I was about to draw.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: If you come there,
Thy beard shall serve to stuff, those balls by which
I get me heat at tennis.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Is he gone.
I would he durst a stood to this awhile,
Well I shall catch him in a narrow room,
Where neither of us can flinch; If I do,
I will make him dance a trenchmoor to my sword,
Come I will along with you to the widow.
We will not be out-braved, take my word,
We will not be wronged while I can draw a sword.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Throte and other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Let the Coach stay at Showlane end: be ready,
Let the boot stand open, and when she is in:
Hurry towards Saint Gyles in the field,
As if the Devil himself were waggoner,
Now for an arm of oak, and heart of steel,
To bare away the wench, to get a wife,
A gentlewoman, a maid, nay which is more,
An honest maid, and which is most of all,
A rich and honest maid: O Jove Jove!
For a man to wed such a wife as this,
Is to dwell in the very suburbs of Heaven,

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Is she so exquisite.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir she is rich
And a great heir.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: It is the more dangerous,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dangerous? Lord where be those gallant spirits,
The time has been when scarce an honest woman,
Much less a wench could pass an Inn of court,
But some of the fry would have been doing
With her: I knew the day when Shreds a Taylor
Coming once late by an Inn of Chancery,
Was laid a long, and muffled in his cloak,
His wife took in, Stitched up, turned out again,
And he persuaded all was but in jest,
Tut those brave boys are gone, these which are left,
Are wary lads, live poring on their books,
And give their linen to their laundresses,
By tail, they now can save their purses,
I knew when every gallant had his man.
But now a twelvepenny weekly Laundress,
Will serve the turn to half a dozen of them,
Here comes my man, what news.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: As you would wish.
The Lady Somer-field is come to town,
Her horses yet are walking, and her men say,
Her only daughter, is conveyed away,
No man knows how: now to it mast,
You and your Servant Dash are made for ever
If you but stick to it now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Now show yourselves at full, and not a man,
But shares a fortune with me if I speed.

div2.stage: Enter William Smal-shanke Boutcher. Thomas Smal-shanke, Francis and Bear. with a torch.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Tut fear not us be sure you run away,
And we will perform the quarrel.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Stand close, they come,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Art sure he will be here.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Most sure.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Beard.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Bear up the torch, and keep your way apace
Directly to the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Have you a License,
Look to that brother before you marry,
For fear the Parson lose his benefice.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Tut our Curate craves no license, he swears
His living came to him by a miracle,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How by miracle?

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why he paid nothing fort,
He swears that few be free from Simony,
But only welshmen, and those he says too,
Are but mountain Priests.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: But hang him fool he lies,
What is his reason?

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: His reason is this,
That all their livings are so rude and bare,
That not a man, will venture his damnation
By giving money for them: he does protest,
There is but two pair, of hose, and shoes,
In all his Parish.

sp.speaker: 1, Gen.
sp.l: Hold up your light Sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Shall I be taught how to advance my torch,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What is the matter Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: 2. Ge.
sp.l: Your Lieutenants

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How an ass; die men like dogs.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: hold gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: An ass, an ass.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Hold brother hold, Lieutenant.
Put up as you are men, your wife is gone.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Gone.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Gone.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: How, which way? this is some plot,

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Down toward Fleet bridge.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: So has the wench let us pursue a aloof,
And see the event, this will prove good mirth,
When things unshaped shall have a perfect birth.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter W. Smal-shancke Boucher, Thom. Smal. and Beard, their swords drawne.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: It is a thing unpossible, they should be gone
Thus far and we not see them.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Upon my life.
They went in by the Grey-hound, and so struck,
Into Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What should she make there;

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Take water at the dock.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Water at Dock,
A fico for her Dock, you will not be ruled.
You will still be obstinate, I will pawn my fate,
She took along shew-lane, and so went home,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Home.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Aye home; how could she chose but go,
Seeing so many naked tools at once,
Drawn in the street?

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: What scurvy luck was this,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Come we will find her, or we will fire the Suburbs,
Put up your tools, let us first along show-lane,
Then straight up Holborne, If we find her not;
We will thence direct to Throtes, if she be lost
I am undone and all your hopes are crossed.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Sir Oliuer Smaleshankes, Iustice Tutchim, Mistris Tafata, Adriana.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Widow I must be short.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: Sir Oliuer,
Will you shame yourself, ha? You must be short,
Why what a word was that to tell a widow?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: I meant I must be brief.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tut.
sp.l: Why say so then,
Yet that is almost as ill; go to, speak on.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Widow I must be brief, what old men do,
They must do quickly.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Then good sir do it,
Widows are seldom slow to put men to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: And old men know their cues, my Love you know,
Has been protested long, and now I come
To make my latest tender, an old grown oak
Can keep you from the rain, and stands as fair
And portly as the best

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Yet search him well,
And we shall find no pith or hearty Timber
To underlay a building.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: I would that Oak
Had been a fire: Forward good sir Oliuer,
Your Oak is naught: stick not too much to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: If you can like, you shall be Ladyfied.
Live at the court, and soon be got with child,
What do you think we old men can do nothing?

sp.speaker: Iu: Tut:
sp.l: This was somewhat like:

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You shall have Jewels,
A Baboon, Parrot, and an Iceland Dog,
And I myself to bear you company.
Your Jointer is five hundred pound by year,
Besides your Plate, your Chains and household stuff,
When envious fate shall change this mortal life.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: But shall I not be over-cloyed with love?
Will you nor be too busy shall I keep
My chamber by the month, if I be pleased
To take Physic, to send for Visitants,
To have my maid read Amadis de Gaule,
Or Donzel del Phoebo to me? shall I have
A Carotch of the last edition,
The Coachman's seat a good way from the Coach,
That if some other Ladies and myself
Chance to talk bawdy, he may not overhear us.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: All this and more.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Shall we have two chambers?
And will you not presume unto my bed,
Till I shall call you by my waiting maid.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And when I send her,
Will you not entice her to your lust,
Nor tumble her before you come to me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay let him do his worst, make your match sure,
And scare not me, I never yet did fear
Any thing my master could do to me.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What noise is that, go see Adriana,
And bring me word: I am so haunted
With a swaggering Captain, that swears God bless us
Like a very Termagant, a Rascal knave,
That says he will kill all men which seeks to wed me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O Mistress! Captain Puff half drunk, is now
Coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O God have you no room
Beyond this Chamber, has sworn to kill me,
And piss in my very physiognomy,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What are you afraid Sir Oliuer?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not afraid,
But of all men I love not to meddle with a Drunkard:
Have you any Room backwards.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: None Sir.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: Is there ne'er a Trunk or Cubbert for him,
Is there ne'er a hole backwards to hide him in.

sp.speaker: Cap. Pu.
sp.l: I must speak with her.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O God he comes.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Creep under my Mistress Farthingale Knight,
That is the best and safest place in the Chamber.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Aye there, there, that he will never mistrust.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Enter Knight, keep close, gather yourself
Round like a Hedge-hog stir not what ever you hear,
See or smell Knight, God bless us, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ca. Pu.
sp.l: Bless thee widow and wife.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir get you gone.
Leave my house, or I will have you conjured
With such a spell, you never yet have heard of,
Have you no other place to vent your froth,
But in my house, is this the fittest place,
Your Captainship can find to puff in: ha!

sp.speaker: Ca Pu.
sp.l: How, am I not thy spouse, didst thou not say,
These arms should clip thy naked body fast,
Betwixt two linen sheets, and be sole Lord
Of all thy pewter-work, thy word is past,
And know that man is powder, dust, and earth,
That shall once dare to think thee for his wife.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: How now you slave, one call the Constable.

sp.speaker: C. Puf.
sp.l: No Constable with all his Holberteeres,
Dare once advance his head, or peep up stairs,
If I cry but keep down: have I not lived,
And marched on the sieged walls,
In thunder, lightning, rain, and snow,
And eke in shot of powdered balls,
Whose costly marks are yet to show?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Captain Face, for my last husbands sake,
With whom you were familiarly acquainted,
I am content to wink at these rude tricks,
But hence, trouble me no more, if you do,
I shall lay you fast, where you shall see
No Sun or Moon.

sp.speaker: C, Puf.
sp.l: Nor yet the Northern Pole,
A fico for the Sun and Moon, let me live in a hole,
So these two stars may shine.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir, get you gone,
You swaggering, cheating, Turne-bul-streete rogue,
Or I will hale you to the common-jail,
Where Lice shall eat you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Go to, I shall spurn
And slash your petticoat.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Run to the Counter,
Fetch me a red-bearded Sergeant, I will make
You Captain think the Devil of hell is come
To fetch you, if he once fasten on you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Damn thee and thy Sergeants, thou Mercers Punk.
Thus will I kick thee and thy Farthingales.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Hold Captain.

sp.speaker: C Pu.
sp.l: What do you cast your whelps.
What have I found you sir? have not I placed
My Sakers, Culverings, Demi-culuerings,
My Cannons, Demi-cannons, Basilisks,
Upon her breach, and do I not stand,
Ready with my Pike to make my entry,
And are you come to man her?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good Captain hold.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Are not her Bulwarks Parapets, Trenches,
Scarfs, Counter-scarfs, Fortifications,
Curtains, Shadows, Mines, Counter-mines,
Rampires, Forts, Ditches, Works, Waterworks,
And is not her half moon mine, and do you bring
A rescue good-man Knight

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Call up my men,
Where be these knaves, have they no ears or hearts,
Beat hence this rascal, some other fetch a warrant,
I will teach him know himself.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Down with the slave.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: It is not your beard shall carry it, down with the rogue.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Not Hercules against twenty.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: A sirrah,
I knew my hands no longer could forbear him,
Why did you not strike the Knave, sir Oliuer?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Why so I did.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: But then it was too late.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: What would you have me do when I was down,
And he stood thundering with his weapon drawn,
Ready to cut my throte.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The rogue is gone,
And here is one from the Lady Somerfield,
To entreat you come with all the speed you can,
To Saint Iohns street.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Which I will do.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Gentlemen
I am sorry you should be thus disturbed
Within my house, but now all fear is past,
You are most welcome: supper ended,
I will give a gracious answer to your suit,
Mean while let naught dismay, or keep you mute.

div2.stage: Ex. Enter Throte, Francis, and Dash.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Pay the Coachman Dash, pay him well,
And thank him for his speed. Now Uiuat Rex,
The knot is knit, which not the law itself,
With all his Hydra heads and strongest nerves,
Is able to disjoin: Now let him hang,
Fret out his guts, and swear the stars from Heaven,
He never shall enjoy you, you shall be rich.
Your Lady mother this day came to town
In your pursuit: we will but shift some rags,
And straight go take her blessing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That must not be,
Furnish me with Jewels, and then myself,
Attended by your man and honest Beard,
Will thither first, and with my Lady mother
Crave a peace for you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I like that well,
Her anger some-what calmed, I brisk and fine,
Some half hour after will present myself
As son in law unto her, which she must needs
Accept with gracious looks.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Aye when she knows
Before by me, from what an eminent plague
Your wisdom has preserved me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Aye, that, that,
That will strike it dead: but here comes Beard.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What are you sure, tide fast by heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I now do call her wife, she now is mine,
Sealed and delivered by an honest Priest,
At Saint Giles in the field.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: God give you joy sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: But where is mad Smal-shanke.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O hard at hand,
And almost mad with loss of his fair bride,
Let not my lovely Mistress be seen,
And see if you can draw him to compound
For all his title to her, I have Sergeants
Ready to do the feat, when time shall serve.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Stand you aside dear love nay I will firk
My silly novice, as he was never firked
Since Midwives bound his noddle: here they come.

div2.stage: Enter W. Smallsh. Th. Smalsh. and Boucher.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: O Master Throte, unless you speak good news,
My hopes are crossed, and I undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I never thought you would come to other end,
Your courses have been always so profane,
Extravagant and base.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Nay good sir hear?
Did not my love return? came she not hither,
For Jove's love speak.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir will you get you gone,
And seek your love elsewhere; for know my house
Is not to entertain such customers
As you and your comrades.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Is the man mad,
Or drunk, why Master Throte know you to whom
You talk so saucily?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why unto you,
And to your brother Smale-shaneks, will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Nay good sir hold us not in this suspense,
Answer directly, came not the Virgin hither.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Will you be gone directly, are you mad?
Come you to seek a Virgin in Ram-alley
So near an Inn of Court, and amongst Cooks,
Ale-men and Laundresses, why are you fools?

sp.speaker: W Sm.
sp.l: Sir leave this firck of law, or by this light
I will give your throte a slit, came she not hither?
Answer to that point.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What, have you lost her?
Come do not gull your friends.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Unless she be returned since we last left you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Nay then I cry you mercy, she came not hither
As am an honest man: Is it possible
A maid so lovely, fair, so well demeaned,
Should be took from you? what from you three?
So young, so brave and valiant Gentlemen?
Sure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: T. Sm.
sp.l: A fore God it is true.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: To our pivotal shames it is now too true.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is she not left behind you in the Tavern?
Are you sure you brought her out? were you not drunk
And so forgot her?

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: A pox on all such luck,
I will find her, or by this good light
I will fire all the City, come let us go,
Who ever has her shall not long enjoy her,
I will prove a contract, let us walk the round,
I will have her if she keep above the ground.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, he makes me sport. i'faith
The gull is mad, stark mad, Dash draw the bond
And a release of all his interest
In this my loved wife,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Aye be sure of that,
For I have certain goblins in buff Jerkins
Lie in ambuscado for him.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I arrest you sir:

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Rescue, rescue.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: O he is caught.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: I will give you bail
Hang off honest catch-poles

sp.speaker: M. Thr.
sp.l: good, wise,
Learned, and honest master Throte, now, now,
Now or never help me.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Here are two retainers, hangers on sir,
Which will consume more than ten liveries,
If by your means they be not straight shook off:
I am arrested.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Arrested? what is the sum?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: But thirteen pound, due to Beard the Butler,
Do but bail me, and I will save you harmless.

sp.speaker: Thr,
sp.l: Why here is the end of Riot, I know the law,
If you be bailed by me, the debt is mine,
Which I will undertake.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Law there; Rogues,
Foot I know he would not let me want
For thirteen pounds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Provided, you seal a release,
Of all your claim to Mistress Somerfield.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Sergeants do your kind, hale me to the hole,
Seal a release, Sergeants come, to prison,
Seal a release for Mistress Somerfield,
First I will stink in Jail, be eat with Lice,
Endure an object worse than the Devil himself,
And that is ten Sergeants peeping through the grates
Upon my lousy linen, come to Jail,
Foot a release.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: There is no conscience in it.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: It is a demand uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Nay choose.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I can hold no longer, impudent man.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: My wife, foot my wife, let me go Sergeants.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O thou perfidious man darest thou presume
To call her wife, whom thou so much hast wronged,
What conquest hast thou got, to wrong a maid,
A silly harmless maid? what glory is it
That thou hast thus deceived a simple, Virgin,
And brought her from her friends? what honour wast
For thee to make the Butler lose his office
And run away with thee. Your tricks are known,
Didst thou not swear thou shouldest be Baronized?
And hadst both lands and fortunes? both which thou wantest.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot that is not my fault, I would have lands
If I could get them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I know your trick;
And know I now am wise unto this man.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I thank her sir, she has now vouchsafed
To cast herself on me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Therefore subscribe,
Take some-what of him for a full release,
And pray to God to make you an honest man,
If not, I do protest by earth and Heaven,
Although I starve, thou never shalt enjoy me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Her vow is past, nor will she break her word,
Look to it mitcher.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I hope he will compound.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot shall I give two thousand pound a year
For nothing.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Brother come, be ruled by me,
Better to take a little than lose all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You see she is resolute, you had best compound.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I will first be damned ere I will lose my right,
Unless he give me up my forfeit mortgage,
And bail me of this action.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir you may choose,
What is the mortgage worth?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: let us have no whispering.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Some forty pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do it, do it,
Come you shall do it, we will be rid of him
At any rate.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dash; go fetch his mortgage,
See that your friends be bound, you shall not claim
Title, right, possession in part or whole,
In time to come, in this my loved wife:
I will restore the mortgage, pay this debt,
And set you free.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: They shall not.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: We will,
Come draw the bonds, and we will soon subscribe them.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: They are ready drawn; here is his release,
Sergeants let him go.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: Here is the mortgage sir.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Was ever man thus cheated of a wife:
Is this my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The very same sir.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Well I will subscribe, God give your joy,
Although I have but little cause to wish it,
My heart will scarce consent unto my hand,
It is done.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You give this as your deeds.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We do,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Certify them Dash.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What am I free.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You are, Sergeants I discharge you,
There is your fees.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Not so, I must have money.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I will pass my word.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Foutre, words are wind,
I say I must have money.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: How much sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Three pounds in hand, and all the rest tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: There is your sum, now officers begone,
Each take his way, I must to Saint Iohns street,
And see my Lady-mother: she is now in town,
And we to her shall straight present our duties.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: O Jove shall we lose the wench thus.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Even thus
Throte farewell, since it is thy luck to have her,
I still shall pray, you long may live together:
Now each to his affairs.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Good night to all,
Dear wife step in, Beard and Dash come hither:
here take this money: go borrow Jewels
Of the next Gold-smith: Beard take thou these books,
Go both to the Brokers in Fetter lane,
Lay them in pawn for a Velvet Jerkin
And a double Ruff, tell him he shall have
As much for loan tonight, as I do give
Usually for a whole circuit, which done
You two shall man her to her mothers: go,
My fate looks big; methinks I see already,
Nineteen gold chains, seventeen great beards, and ten
Reverent bald heads, proclaim my way before me,
