My Coach shall now go prancing through Cheapside,
And not be forced to hurry through the streets,
For fear of Sergeants: nor shall I need to try,
Whether my well-grassed tumbling foot-cloth nag,
Be able to outrun a weal-breathed Catch pole,
I now in pomp will ride, for it is most fit,
He should have state that riseth by his wit.

div2.stage: Actus 4. Scæna. 1. Sir Oliuer, Iustice Tutchim, Taffata, Adriana.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good meat the belly fills, good wine the brain,
Women please men, men pleasure them again,
Ka me, ka thee, one thing must rub another,
English love Scots, Welshmen love each other.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: You say very right sir Oliuer, very right,
I have it in my noddle i'faith, That is all the fault
Old Justices have, when they are at feasts,
They will bib hard, they will be fine: Sun-burnt
Sufficient, foxed, or Columberd now and than,
Now could I sit in my chair at home and nod
drunkard to the stocks, by virtue of,
The last statute fairly.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir you are merry,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Your supper sir was light.
But I hope you think you welcome.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I do,
A light supper quoth you, pray God it be,
Pray god I carry it cleanly, I am sure it lies,
As heavy in my belly as moult lead,
Yet I will go see my Sister Sommerfield,

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: So late good Justice.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Aye even so late,
Night is the mother of wit, as you may see,
By Poets or rather Constables
In their examinations at midnight,
We will lie together without marrying,
Save the Curate's fees, and the parish a labour,
It is a thriving course.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: That may not be,
For excommunications then will flee.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: That is true, they fly indeed like weld-geese,
In flocks, one in the breech of another.
But the best is a small matter stays them,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: Farewell good Justice Tutchim,
Alas good gentleman his brains are erased,
But let that pass: speak widow is it a match,
Shall we clap it up.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay if it come to clapping,
Good night i'faith Mistress look before you,
There is nothing more dangerous to maid or widow,
Than sudden clapings up; nothing has spoiled,
So many proper ladies as clappings up:
Your shuttlecocks, striding from tables to ground,
Only to try the strength of the back,
Your riding a hunting, Aye though they fall,
With their heels upward, and lay as if
They were taking the height, of some high star
With a cross staff: no nor your iumlings
In horsslitters, coaches or caroatches,
Have spoiled so many women as clappings up,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: Why then we will chop it up.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: That is not allowed.
Unless you were son to a welsh Curate:
But faith sir Knight I have a kind of Itching,
To be a Lady, that I can tell you woes,
And can persuade with better rhetoric,
Than oaths, wit, wealth, valour, lands, or person,
I have some debts at court, and marrying you,
I hope the Courtier will not stick to pay me,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: Never fear thy payment. This I will say,
For Courtiers they will be sure to pay each other,
How ever they deal with Citizens.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Then here is my hand,
I am your wife condition we be joined,
Before tomorrow's sun.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: Nay even tonight,
So you be pleased with little warning widow,
We old men can be ready, and thou shalt see,
Before the time that chanticleers,
Shall call and tell the day is near,
When wenches lying on their backs,
Receive with joy their love-stolen smacks,
When maids awaked from their first sleep,
Deceived with dreams begin to weep,
And think if dreams, such pleasures know,
What sport the substance them would show,
When Ladies gin white Limbs to spread,
Her love but new stolen to her bed,
His cotton shows yet scarce put off,
And dares not laugh, speak, sneeze, or cough,
When precise dames begin to think,
Why their gross souring husbands stink,
What pleasure it were then to enjoy,
A nimble vicar, or a boy.
Before this time thou shalt behold,
Me quaffing out our bridal bole.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Then belike before the morning Sun
You will be coupled.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Yes faith Adriana,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Well I will look you shall have a clean smock,
Provided that you pay the fee Sir Oliuer,
Since my Mistress sir will be a Lady,
I will lose no fees due to the waiting maid.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Why is there a fee belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A Knight and never heard of smock fees,
I would I had the monopoly of them,
So there were no impost set upon them:

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Whom have we here what my mad-headed son
What makes he here so late? say I am gone,
And I the whilst will step behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: God Bless thee parcel of man's flesh,

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: How sir.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why parcel of man's flesh art not a woman?
But widow where is the old stinkard my father,
They say widow you dance altogether.
After his pipe.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: What then.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Thou art a fool,
I will assure thee there is no music in it.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Can you play better.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Better widow?
Blood dost think I have not learnt my prick song,
What not the court prick song? one up and another down,
Why I have it to a hare by this light,
I hope thou lovest him not.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I will marry him sir,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: How marry him, foot art mad widow,
Would marry an old crazed man,
With meagre looks, with visage wan,
With little legs and crinkled thighs,
With Chap fallen gums and deep sunk eyes,
Why a dog seized on ten days by death
Stinks nor so loathsome as his breath,
Nor can a city common iaques,
Which all men's Breeches undertakes,
Yield fasting stomachs such a favour.
As doth his breath, and ugly favour.

sp.speaker: S, O.
sp.l: Rogue,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: That is all one sir she means to be a Lady,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Does she so, and thou must be her waiting woman.
Faith thou wilt make a fine dainty creature,
To sit at a chamber door and look fleas,
In thy Ladies dog while she is showing,
Some slippery breeched Courtier rare faces,
In a by window, foot widow,
Marry me a young and complete gallant,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: How a complete gallant? what? a fellow,
With a hat tucked up behind, and what we use,
About our hips to keep our coats from dabbling,
He wears about his neck, a farthingale:
A standing collar to keep his neat band clean,
The whilst his shirt does stink, and is more foul,
Than an inn of chancery table cloth,
His breeches must be plaited as if he had
Some thirty pockets, when one poor halfpenny purse,
Will carry all his treasure, his knees all points,
As if his legs and hams were tide together,
A fellow that hasno inside, but prates
By rote, as players, and parrots use to do,
And to define a complete gallant right,
A mercer formed him, a taylor made him,
And a player gives him sprite,

sp.speaker: Wi. Sm.
sp.l: Why so, in my conscience to be a Countess,
Thou wouldst marry a hedgehog: I must confess,
It is state to have a coxcomb kiss your hands,
While yet the chamberly is scarce wiped off,
To have an upright usher march before you,
Bare headed in a Tuftafata jerkin
Maid of your old cast gown, shows passing well,
But when you feel your husbands pulses, that is hell,
Then you fly out and bid straight smocks farewell,

sp.speaker: Taf,
sp.l: I hope sir what ever our husbands be,
We may be honest.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: May be; nay you are,
Women and honesty are as near allied,
As parsons lives are to their doctrines,
One and the same: but widow now be ruled,
I hope the heavens will give thee better grace,
Than to accept the father and I yet live,
To be bestowed, if you wed the stinkard,
You shall find the tale of Tantalus
To be no fable widow.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: How I sweat,
I can hold no longer, degenerate bastard,
I here disclaim thee, cashier thee, nay more,
I disinherit thee both of my love.
And living, get thee a gray cloak and hat
And walk in Paules amongst thy cashiered mates
As melancholy as the best:

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come not near me,
I forbid thee my house, my out-houses,
My Garden, Orchard, and my backside,
Thou shalt not harbour near me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Nay to thy grief,
Know varlet I will be wed this morning,
Thou shalt not be there, nor once be graced
With a piece of Rosemary: I will cashier thee,
Do not reply, I will not stay to hear thee.

sp.speaker: W. Sm:
sp.l: Now may I go put me on a clean shirt
And hang myself, foot who would have thought
The Fox had earthed so near me; what is to be done?
What miracle shall I now undertake
To win respective grace with God and men?
What if I turned Courtier and lived honest?
Sure that would do it: I dare not walk the streets,
For I dwindle at a Sergeant in buff
Almost as much as a new Player does
At a plague bill certified forty:
Well I like this widow, a lusty plump drab
Has substance both in breach and purse,
And pity and sin it were she should be wed
To a furred cloak and a night-cap. I will have her,
This widow I will have: her money
Shall pay my debts and set me up again,
It is here, it is almost forged, which if it take,
The world shall praise my wit, admire my fate.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Beard, Dash, Francis, Sargeant, Drawers.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Sergeants beware, be sure you not mistake,
For If you do.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: She shall be quickly bailed:
She shall Corpus cum causa be removed,
Your action entered first below, shall shrink,
And you shall find sir Sergeant she has friends
Will stick to her in the common place.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Sir
Will you procure her bail:

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: She shall be bailed,
Drawer bring up some wine, use her well,
Her husband is a Gentleman of sort

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: A Gentleman of sort, why what care I:
A woman of her fashion shall find
More kindness at a lusty Sergeants hand
Than ten of your Gentlemen of sort.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: Sir use her well, she is wife to Master Throte:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: I will use her sir as if she were my wife,
Would you have any more.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Whilst we go fetch her bail.
fellow Dash,
With all the speed thou hast run for our Master,
Make haste lest he be gone before thou comest,
To Lady Somerfields: I will fetch another,
She shall have bail.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: And a firking writ
Of false imprisonment, she shall be sure
Of twelve-pence damage, and five and twenty pound
For suits in law: I will go fetch my Master.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And I another:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Drawer leave the Room
here Mistress a health:

sp.speaker: Fra:
sp.l: Let it come sweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Dra:
sp.l: Aye, say you so: then must I have an eye,
These Sergeants feed on very good reversions,
On Capons, Teals, and sometimes on a Woodcock
Hot from the shrieues own table, the knaves feed well
Which makes them horrid lechers.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This health is pledged
And honest Sergeant how does master Gripe
The keeper of the Counter, I do protest
I found him always favourable to me,
He is an honest man, has often stood to me,
And been my friend and let me go a trust
For victual when he denied it knights: but come,
Let us pay and then begone, the arrest you know
Was but a trick to get from nimble Dash
My husbands man:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: True but I have an action
At suit of Mistress, Sel-smocke, your quondam Bawd,
The sum is eight good pound, for six weeks board,
And five weeks loan for a red Tafata gown
Bound with a silver lace:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do protest,
By all the honesty betwixt thee and me,
I got her in that gown in six weeks space
Four pound and fourteen pence given by a Clarke
Of an Inn of Chancery, that night I came
Out of her house, and does the filthy Jade
Send to me for money? but honest Sergeant,
Let me go, and say thou didst not see me,
I will do thee as great a pleasure shortly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Shall we embrace tonight.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sit on my knee and kiss,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What news boy? why stand you Sentinel?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Do but conceal yourself, and we shall catch
My Sergeant napping.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Shall maids be here deflowered,

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Now kiss again.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Now, now.

div2.stage: Enter Cap. and seeing the hurly burly, runs away.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Deflower virgins, rogue? avaunt ye slave,
Are maids fit subjects for a Sergeant's mace.
So now are we once more free: there is for the wine.
Now to our Randeuow: three pounds in gold
These flops contain; we will quaff in Venice glasses,
And swear some Lawyers are but silly Asses.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Is the coast clear, are these combustions ceased,
And may we drink Canary sack in peace?
Shall we have no attendance here you rogues,
Where be these rascals that skip up and down,
Faster than Virginal iacks? drawers.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: On whom wait you sir rogue?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Faith Captain
I attend a conventicle of Players.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: How players, what is there ever a Cuckold among them?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Jove defend else, it stands with policy,
That one should be a notorious Cuckold,
If it be but for the better keeping
The rest of his company together.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: When did you see sir Theophrastus Slop,
The City Dog-maister?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Not today sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What have you for my supper.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Nothing ready
Unless you please to stay the dressing Captain,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'swounds stay the dressing; you damned rogue,
What shall I wait upon your greasy cook,
And wait his leisure, go down stairs rogue,
Now all her other customers be served,
Ask if your Mistress have a snip of Mutton
Yet left for me.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And good-man rogue
See what good thing your Kitchen-maid has left
For me to work upon, my barrow-gutlings grumble
And would have food: Say now the Vintners wife
Should bring me up a Pheasant, Partridge, Quail,
A pleasant banquet, and extremely love me,
Desire me to eat, kiss, and protest,
I should pay nothing for it, say she should drink
Herself three quarters drunk, to win my love,
Then give me a chain, worth some three score pounds,
Say it were worth but forty, say but twenty,
For Citizens do seldom in their wooing,
Give above twenty pounds: say then it is twenty,
I will go sell some fifteen pounds worth of the chain,
To buy some clothes, and shift my lousy linen,
And wear the rest as a perpetual favour,
About my arm in fashion of a Bracelet,
Say then her husband should grow jealous,
I would make him drunk, and then I will Cuckold him,
But then a Vintners wife, some Rogues will say,
Which sits at Bar for the receipt of custom,
That smells of chippings and of broken fish,
Is love to Captain Face, which to prevent,
I will never come but when her best stitched hat,
Her Bowgle gown and best wrought smock is on,
Then does she neither smell of bread, of meat,
Or droppings of the tap, it shall be so.

div2.stage: Enter Boutcher, W. Smalshanke, and Constantia.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Now leave us boy; bless you Captain Face.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will have no Music?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot doest take us for fiddlers

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then turn straight, Drawer run down the stares,
And thank the Gods he gave me that great patience
not to strike you.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Your patience sir is great,
For you dare seldom strike. Sirrah they say,
You needs will wed the widow Taffata,
Nolens volens.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Do not urge my patience,
Awake not fury, new raked up in embers,
I give you leave to live.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Men say you have tricks,
You are an admirable Ape, and you can do
More feats than three Baboons, we must have some.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My patience yet is great, I say be gone,
My tricks are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: That is nothing,
I have brought you furniture, come get up
Up upon this table, do your feats,
Or I will whip you to them, do not I know
You are a lousy knave.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How? Lousy knave,
Are we not English bred?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You are a coward Rogue.
That dares not look a Kitling in the face,
If she but stare or mew.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My patience yet is great:
Do you bandy troops, by This I will be Knight,
Wear a blue coat on great Saint Georges day,
And with my fellows drive you all from Paules
For this attempt.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Will you yet gee up,
I must lash you to it,

sp.speaker: Cvp.
sp.l: By Pluto, Gentlemen,
To do you pleasure, and to make you sport,
I will do it.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Come get up then quick.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will dress you sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By Jove it is not for fear,
But for a love I bear unto these tricks,
That I perform it.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Hold up your snout sir,
Sit handsomely, by heaven, sir you must do it,
Come boy.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: No by this good light, I willplay
Him that goes with the motions.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Where is the Captain Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Stand back boy, and be a spectator, Gentlemen
You shall see the strange nature of an outlandish beast,
That has but two legs, bearded like a man,
Nosed like a Goose, and tongued like a woman,
Lately brought from the land of Catita,
A beast of much understanding, were it not given
Too much to the love of Venery: do I not do it well?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Admirably.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Remember noble Captain,
You skip when I shall shake my whip: Now sit,
What can you do for the great Turke?
What can you do for the Pope of Room?
Hark, he stirreth not, he moveth not, he waggeth not,
What can you do for the town of Geneua sirrah?

div2.stage: He holds vp his hands insteed of praying.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sure this Baboon is a great Puritan.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Is not this strange.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Not a whit by this light,
Banks his horse and he were taught both in a stable.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.l: O rare.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'swounds I will first be damned, shall sport
Be laughed at; by This, by Pluto, and great Proserpine,
My fatal blade once drawn, falls but with death,
Yet if you will let me go, I vow by Jove,
No widow, maid, wife, punk, or Cockatrice,
Shall make me haunt your ghosts.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: It will not serve sir,
You must show more.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will first be hanged and damned.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot canhe jump so well.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Is he so quick?
I hope the slave will haunt no more the widow.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: As for that take no care, for by this light
She will not have thee.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Not have me?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: No not have thee,
By this hand, flesh, and blood, she is resolved
To make my father a most fearful Cuckold,
And he is resolved to save his soul by her.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How by her?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Thus, all old men which marry
Young wives, shall questionless be saved,
For while they are young, they keep other men's wives,
And when they are old, they keep wives for other men,
And so by satisfaction procure salvation.
Why thou dejected tail of a Crab,
Does not the fair Constantia Somerfield
Dote on thy filthy face; and wilt thou wed
A wanton widow? what canst thou see
To dote on her.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Only this, I love her.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.p: Doest love her then, take a purgation, For love I will assure thee is a binder: Of all things under heaven, there is no fitter parallels than a Drunkard and a Lover: for a drunkard looses his senses, so does your lover; your drunkard is quarrelsome, so is your lover: your drunkard will swear, lie, and speak great words, so will your lover: your drunkard is most desirous of his lechery, and so is your lover: Well the night grows old, farewell:
sp.l: I am so much thy friend, that none shall bed thee,
While fair Constantia is resolved to wed thee.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Foot shall we let the wench go thus,
My masters now show yourselves Gentlemen
And take a way the Lawyers wife;
Foot though I have no wit, yet I can,
Love a wench and choose a wife,

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Why sir, what should you do with a wife, that are held none of the wisest? you will get none but fools.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.p: How fools, why may not I a fool get a wise child as well as wise men get fools: all lies but in the agility of the woman: In troth I think all fools are got when there mothers asleep; therefore I will never lie with my wife but when she is broad waking, stand to it honest friends, knock down the Lieutenant and then hurry the wench to Fleet-street, there my father and I will this morning be married.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Stand close they come.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: By Jove the night grows dark and Luna looks,
As if this hour some fifty cuckolds were making,
Then let us trudge.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Down with them, down with them, away with her Master Smal-shankes to Fleet street, go the Curate there stays for you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And stays the Curate.
What is here knocked down, and blood of men let out,
Must men in darkness bleed, then Erebus look big,
And Boreas blow the fire of all my rage,
Into his nose. Night thou art a whore,
Smalshanke a rogue: and is my wench took from me,
Sure I am gulled, this was no Cockatrice,
I never saw her before this day-light peeped,
What dropest thou head, this surely is the heir,
And mad will Smal-shankes lay in Ambuscado,
To get her now from me, Beard: Lieutenant Beard,
Thou art an asses what a dull slave was I,
That all this while smelt not her honesty.
Pate I do not pity thee: hadst thou brains,
Lieutenant Beard had got this wealthy heir,
From all these rogues, blood to be this orereached,
In pate and wench: revenge, revenge come up,
And with thy curled locks cling to my beard,
Smale-shamkes I will betray thee: I now will trudge,
To Saint Iohns street to inform the Lady Sommerfield,
Where thou art: I will prevent the match,
Thou art to Fleet street gone, revenge shall follow,
And my incensed wrath shall like great thunder,
Disperse thy hopes and thy brave wife a sunder.

div2.stage: Enter Lady Sommerfield, and Iustice Tutchin.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: Say as I say widow, the wench is gone,
But I know whether, stolen she is, well.
I know by whom, say as I say widow,
I have been drinking hard, why say so too,
Old men they can be fine, with small a do,
The law is not offended, I had no punk,
Nor in an alehouse, have I made me drunk.
The statute is not broke, I have the skill,
To drink by law, then say as I say still,

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: To what extremes doth this licentious time,
Hurry unstayed youth, nor Gods nor Laws,
Whose penal scourges are enough to save,
Even damned fiends, can in this looser age,
Confine unbounded youth, who durst presume,
To steal my youths delight, my ages hope,
Her fathers heir, and the last noble stem,
Of all her ancestors: fear they or Gods or laws.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I say as you say sister, but for the laws,
There are so many that men do stand in awe,
Of none at all; take heed they steal not you.
Who woes a widow with a fair full Moon
Shall surely speed, beware of full Moons widow,
Will Smalshankes has your daughter no word but mum,
My warrant you shall have when time shall come.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: your warrant?

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Aye my warrant widow.
My warrant can stretch far; no more but so,
It will serve to ketch a knave, or fetch a Do.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here is a gentleman much desirous to see you madam.

sp.speaker: La. So.
sp.l: What is a for a man.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nothing for a man, but much for a beast,
I think him lunatic for he demands,
What plate of his is stirring in the house,
He calls your men his Butlers, Cooks, and Steward,
Kisses your woman, and makes exceeding much
Of your Coach-mans wife;

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: Then he is a gentleman, for it is a true note of a gentleman, to make much of other men's wives, bring him up, a sirrah, makes he much of your Coachman's wife, this gear will run a wheels then shortly, A man may make much more of a nother man's wife, than he can do of his own.

sp.speaker: L. S.
sp.l: How much brother?

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p:
A man may make with ease, A Punk, a Child, a Bastard, a Cuckold, of another man's wife all at a clap.
And that is much I think.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: That is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: For that thou first hast brought me to her sight,
I here create thee Clarke a the Kitchen, no man shall beg it from thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure the fellows mad.

sp.speaker: L. S.
sp.l: What would you sir? I guess your long profession,
By your scant suite: your habit seems to turn:
Your inside outward to me; you are I think.
Some Turner of the law.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Law is my living.
And on that ancient mold I wear this outside,
Suite upon suite wastes some yet makes me thrive.
First law, then gold, then love, and then we wive.

sp.speaker: I. T.
sp.l: A man of form like me but what is your business?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Be brief good sir: what makes this bold intrusion?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Intrude, I do not, for I know the law,
It is the rule that squares out all our actions,
Those actions bring in coin, coin gets me friends,
Your son in law hath law at his fingers ends.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My son in law.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Madam your son in law,
Mother I come, (be glad I call you so)
To make a gentle breach into your favour,
And win your approbation of my choice,
Your cherry-ripe sweet daughter (so renowned,
For beauty, virtue, and a wealthy dower)
I have espoused.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How? you espouse my daughter?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Nouerint vniuersi, the laws of heaven,
Of nature, church, and chance, have made her mine,
Therefore deliver her by these presents.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: How is this? made her yours sir? per quam regulam,
Nay we are lettered sir, as well as you,
Redde rationem per quam regulam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Femini ludificantur viros:
By that same rule these lips have taken season,
Tut I do all by Statute law, and reason.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hence you base knave, you petty-fogging groom,
Clad in old ends, and pieced with Brokery,
You wed my daughter?

sp.speaker: I. T.
sp.l: You sir Ambo-dexter,
A Summoners son, and learned in Norfolke wiles,
Some common bail, or Counter Lawyer,
Marry my niece? your half sleeves shall not carry her.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: These Storms will be dissolved in tears of joy,
Mother I doubt it not: Justice to you,
That jerk at my half sleeves, and yet yourself
Do never wear but Buckram out of sight,
A Flannel wast-coate, or a Canvas Truss,
A shift of thrift, I use it: let us be friends,
You know the law hath tricks, ka me, ka thee,
Viderit vtilitas, the mott to these half arms,
Corpus cum causa needs no bumbasting.
We wear small hair yet have we tongue and wit,
Lawyers close breeched have bodies politic.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Speak, answer me sir Iack: stole you my daughter?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Short tale to make, I fingered have your daughter,
I have taken livery and season of the wench,
Deliver her then, you know the Statute laws,
She is mine without exception, bar or clause:
Come, come, restore.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The fellow is mad I think,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I was not mad before I married,
But ipso facto what the act may make me,
That know I not.

sp.speaker: I. T.
sp.l: Fellows come in there,
By this sir you confess you stole my Niece
And I attach you here of felony:
Lay hold on him: I will make my Mittimus,
And send him to the Jail; have we no bar
Nor clause to hamper you, away with him,
Those claws shall claw you to a bar of shame,
Where thou shalt show thy Goll, I will bar your claim,
If I be Justice Tutchin.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Hands off you slaves,
O! favour my Jerkin, though you tear my flesh,
I set more store by that: my Audita
Querela shall be heard, and with a Certiorare
I will fetch her from you with a pox.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What is here to do? is all the world in arms?
More tumults, brawls, and insurrections,
Is blood the Theme whereon our time must treat.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Here is Beard your Butler: a rescue Beard; draw,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Draw? not so: my Blade is as ominously drawn
Unto the death of nine or ten such grooms,
As is a knife unsheathed with the hungry maw,
Threatening the ruin of a chine of Beef:
But for the restless toil it took of late,
My blade shall sleep awhile.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Help.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Stop thee Throate
And hear me speak, whose bloody Characters,
Will show I have been scuffling: briefly thus,
Thy wife, your daughter, and your lovely Niece,
Is hurried now to Fleet-street, the damned crew
With glaives and clubs have rapt her from these arms,
Throate thou art bobbed, although thou boughtest the heir,
Yet hath the slave made a re-entry.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Sirrah what are you?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: My Ladies Butler sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Not I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By this good light he swore it,
And for your daughters love he ran away.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: By Jove I gulled thee Throte.

sp.speaker: I. T.
sp.l: More knavery yet,
Lay hands on him, pinion them both,
And guard them hence towards Fleet-street, come away,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Must we be led like thieves, and pinioned walk,
Spent I my blood for this? is this my hire?
Why then burn rage, set Beard and nose on fire.

sp.speaker: I. T.
sp.l: On, on I say.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Justice, the law shall firk you.

div2.stage: Actus Quinti. Scæna 1. Enter William Small-shanke.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: On this one hour depends my hopes and fortunes,
Foot I must have this widow: what should my Dad
Make with a wife, that scarce can wipe his nose,
Untruss his points, or hold a Chamber-pot,
Steady till he pisses: The doors are fast,
It is now the midst of night; yet shall this chain,
Procure access and conference with the widow:
What though I cheat my father, all men have sins,
Though in their several kinds, all ends in this,
So they get gold, they care not whose it is.
Begging the Court, use bears the City out,
Lawyers their quirks, thus goes the world about,
So that our villainies have but different shapes,
The effects all one, and poor men are but Apes,
To imitate their betters, this is the difference,
All great men's sins must still be humoured,
And poor men's vices largely punished,
The privilege that great men have in evil,
Is this, they go unpunished to the Devil
Therefore I will in, this chain I know will move,
Gold and rich stones, wins coyest ladies love.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: What would you sir, that you do knock so boldly.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I must come in to the widow.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: How come in,
The widow has no entrance for such mates.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Dost hear sweet Chamber-maid, by heaven I come,
With letters from my father, I have brought her stones,
Jewels and chains, which she must use tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: You are a needy knave, and will lie:
Your father has cashiered you, nor will he trust you,
Begone, least I do wash you hence.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Dost hear,
By this good night, my Father and I are friends,
Take but this chain for token, give her that,
And tell her I have other things for her,
Which by my fathers will I am commanded
To give to her own hands.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Say you so,
In troth I think you will prove an honest man,
Had you once got a beard; let me see the chain,

sp.speaker: W. S,
sp.l: Doest think I lie? by this good light Adrian
I love her with my soul, here is letters
And other Jewels sent her from my father,
Is she a bed.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: By my virginity,
She is uncased, and ready to flip in,
Betwixt the sheets, but I will bear her this,
And tell her what you say.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: But make some haste,
Why so it will take, zart how a waiting maid,
Can shake a fellow up that is cashiered,
And has no money: foot should she keep the chain,
And not come down, I must turn Citizen,
Be bankrupt, and crave the Kings protection
But here she comes.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What would you sir with us,
That on the sudden, and so late you come.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I have some secrets to acquaint you with,
Please you to let the chamber maid shake off,
And stand as Sentinel.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: It shall not need,
I hope I have not brought her up so ill,
But that she knows how to contain your secrets,
As well as I her Mistress: Therefore on.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: It is not fit forsooth that I should on,
Before she leave the room.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: It is not indeed.
Therefore I will wait in the with-drawing room
Until you call.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Now sir, what is your will?

sp.speaker: W. S,
sp.l: Dear widow, pity the state of a young,
Poor, yet proper Gentleman, by Venus pap
Upon my knees I would creep unto your lap
For one small drop of favour, and though this face
Is not the finest face, yet it has been praised
By Ladies of good judgment in faces.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Are these your secrets?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: You shall have secrets
More pleasing, nay hear sweet widow,
Some wantons do delight to see men creep,
And on their knees to woe them.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I am none of those,
Stand up, I more desire a man should stand,
Than cringe and creep that means to win my love,
I say stand up, and let me go ye had best.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: For ever let me creep upon the ground,
Unless you hear my suit.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: How now sir sauce,
Would you be capering in your fathers saddle,
Away you cashiered younger brother, begone.
Do not I know the fashions of you all,
When a poor woman has laid open all
Her thoughts to you, then you grow proud and coy,
But when wise maids dissemble and keep close,
Then you poor snakes come creeping on your bellies,
And with all oiled looks prostrate yourselves,
Before our beauties sun, where once but warm,
Like hateful snakes you strike us with your stings,
And then forsake us, I know your tricks begone.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot I will first be hanged, nay if you go
You shall leave your smock behind you widow,
Keep close your womanish weapon, hold your tongue,
Nor speak, cough, sneeze or stamp, for if you do,
By this good blade I will cut your throte directly,
Peace, stir not, by Heaven I will cut your throate
If you but stir: speak not, stand still, go to,
I will teach coy widows a new way to woe,
Come you shall kiss, why so, I will stab by Heaven
If you but stir, now here, first kiss again,
Why so, stir not, Now come I to the point,
My hopes are past, nor can my present state,
Afford a single halfpenny, my father
Hates me deadly; to beg, my birth forbids,
To steal, the law, the hang man, and the Rope
With one consent deny; to go a trust,
The City common-council has forbade it,
Therefore my state is desperate, stir not,
And I by much will rather choose to hang,
Than in a ditch or prison-hole to starve,
Resolve, wed me, and take me to your bed,
Or by my soul I will straight cut off your head,
Then kill myself, for I had rather die,
Than in a street live poor and loosely:
Do not I know you cannot love my father.
A widow that has known the quid of things,
To dote upon an old and crazed man,
That stinks at both ends, worse than an elder pipe,
Who when his blood and spirit are at the height,
Hath not a member to his palsy body,
But is more limber than a Kings head pudding,
Took from the pot half sod do I not know this?
Have you not wealth enough, to serve us both?
And am not I a pretty handsome fellow,
To do your drudgery, come, come, resolve.
For by my blood, if you deny your bed,
I will cut your throat, without equivocation,
If you be pleased hold up your finger, if not
By heaven I will gore my whinyard through your womb,
Is it a match.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: You will prate too loud.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Nor speak one word against my honest suit.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: No by my worth

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Kiss upon that and speak,

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I dare not wed, men say you are naught you will cheat.
And you do keep a whore.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: That is a lie,
She keeps herself and me, yet I protest,
She is not dishonest.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: How could she then maintain you,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why by her comings in, a little thing,
Her friends have left her which with putting to best use.
And often turning yields her a poor living,
But what of that; shes now shook off, to thee
I will only cleave, I will be thy merchant.
And to this wealthy fair, I will bring my ware,
And here set up my standing: therefore resolve,
Naught but my sword is left if it be a match,
Clap hands, contract and straight to bed,
If not, pray, forgive and straight goes off your head.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I take thy love.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Then straight let us both to bed.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: I will wed tomorrow.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: You shall not sleep upon it.
An honest contract is as good as marriage.
A bird in hand you know the proverb widow,

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: To let me tell thee, I will love thee while I live,
For this attempt give me that lusty lad,
That wins his widow with his well drawn blade,
And not with oaths and words: a widows wooing,
Not in bare words but should consist in doing,
I take thee to my husband.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I thee to wife,
Now to thy bed and there we will end this strife.

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: Warm blood the young man's slave, the old man's God
Makes me so stir thus soon, it stirs i'faith,
And with a kind of Itching pricks me on,
To bid my bride bonjour, O this desire,
Is even another filched promethean fire,
By which we old men live, performance then,
Aye that is poor old men's bane, that in old men,
Comes limping off more lame God knows than he,
Which in a close, a hot and dangerous fight,
Has been dismembered and craves by letter patents,
Yet scarce a woman that considers this,
Women have tricks firks and farthingales,
A generation are they full of subtlety,
And all most honest where they want the means.
To be otherwise. Therefore I will have an eye
My widow goes not oft to visit kinsfolks,
By birth she is a Ninny, and that I know,
Is not in London held the smallest kindred,
I must have wits and brains, come on my friends,
Out with your tools, and toot, a strain of mirth.
And a pleasant song to wake the widow.

div2.stage: Enter W. S. aboue in his shirt.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Musicians, minstrels, foot rogues,
For Gods love leave your filthy squeaking noise
And get you gone, the widow and myself,
Will scamble out the shaking of the sheets,
Without your music, we have no need of fiddlers,
To our dancing, foot have you no manners,
Cannot a man take his natural rest.
For your scraping, I shall wash your gut-strings.
If you but stay a while; yet honest rascals,
If you will let us have the the other crash
The widow and I will keep time, there is for your pains,

sp.speaker: S. O.
sp.l: Hows this? will the widow and you keep time,
What trick? what quiddit? what figure is this?
My cashiered Son speak from the widows chamber,
And in his shirt ha, sure she is not there,
It is so she has took him in for pity,
And now removes her chamber I will home,
On with my neatestrobes, perfume my beard,
Eat cloves, Eringoes and drink some aqua-vita.
To sweeten breath and keep my weame from wambling.
Then like the month of March, come blustering in,
Marry the widow shake up this spring all,
And then as quiet as a sucking lamb,
Close by the widow will I rest all night,
As for my breath I have crotchets and devises,
Ladies rank breaths are often helped with spices.

div2.stage: Enter Adriana, and another strawing hearbs.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Come straw a pace, Lord shall I never live,
To walk to Church on flowers. O it is fine,
To see a bride trip it to Church so lightly,
As if her new choppiness would scorn to bruise
A silly flower: and now I prithee tell me,
What flower thinkest thou is likest to a woman?

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: A marigold I think.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why a marigold:

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Because a little heat makes it to spread,
And open wide his leaves.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Thou art quite wide,
A marigold doth open wide all day,
And shuts most close at night; I hope thou knowest,
All wenches do the contrary: but sirrah,
How does thy Uncle the old Doctor,
Dost think he will be a Bishop?

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: O questionless,
For has got him a young wife, and carried her,
To Court already: but now I prithee say,
Why will the widow wed so old a knight,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why for his riches.

sp.speaker: Ui.
sp.l: For riches only,
Why riches cannot give her her delight,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Riches I hope can soon procure her one
Shall give her her delight that is the Devil,
That is it i'faith makes us waiting gentlewomen
Live maids so long.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Yes i'faith,
Married women quite have spoiled the market,
By having secret friends besides their husbands,
For if these married wives would be content
To have but one a piece I think in troth,
There would be doings enough for us all,
And till we get an act of parliament,
For that our states are desperate.
Come straw a piece.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: So ho ho, Master.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Boy,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: In troth I thought you had been more fast asleep,
Than a midwife or a Puritan Taylor,
At a sunday evenings Lecture, but sir
Why do you rise so soon?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: To see the widow,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The weaker you, you are forbid a widow,
And it is the first thing you will fall into.
Methinks a young clear skinned country Gentlewoman,
That never saw Baboons, Lions, or Courtiers,
Might prove a handsome wife, or what do you say
To a Citizens daughter, that never was in love
With a Player, that never learnt to dance,
That never dwelt near any Inn a Court,
Might not she in time prove an honest wife?
Faith take a maid, and leave the widow, Master
Of all meats I love not a gaping Oyster,

sp.speaker: Bou,
sp.l: God speed your works fair maids.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You much mistake,
It is no work.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What then.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A preparation
To a work sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What work sweet Ladies?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why to a marriage? that is a work I think,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How? a preparation to a marriage,
Of whom kind maids, of whom?

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: And why kind maids?
I hope you have had no kindness at our hand,
To make you say so: but sir understand,
That Sir Oliuer Smal-shanke the noble Knight,
And mistress Tafata the rich widow,
Must this day be coupled, conjoined,
Married, espoused, wedded, contracted,
Or as the Puritan says, put together,
And so sir, to the shifting of our clean smocks,
We leave you.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Married, and today,
Dissension, Jealousy, hate, beggary,
With all the dire events which breed dislike
In nuptial beds, attend her bridal steps,
Can vows and oaths, with such protesting action,
As if their hearts were spit forth with their words,
As if their souls were darted through their eyes,
Be of no more validity with women?
Have I for her contemned my fixed fate.
Neglected my fair hopes, and scorned the love
Of beauteous, virtuous, and honoured Constantia.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now works it with my wish: my hopes are full.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: And I engaged my worth and ventured life
On yonder buffolne face, to have men scorn,
And point at my disgrace: first will I leave to live:
There take my purse, live thou to better fate.
Better thus die, than live unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Aye me accursed: help, help, murther murther,
Cursed be the day and hour that gave me breath,
Murther, murther: if any Gentleman
Can hear my plaints, come forth and assist me.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What out-cries call me from my naked bed,
Who calls Ieronimo, speak here I am.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Good sir leave your struggling and acting,
And help to save the life of a distressed man,
O help if you be Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: What is here?
A man hanged up and all the murtherers gone?
And at my door to lay the guilt on me.
This place was made to pleasure Citizens wives,
And not to hang up honest Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Where be these lazy knaves? some raise the house,
What meant the cry of murther? where is my love?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Come Isabella, help me to lament,
For sighs are stopped, and all my tears are spent.
These clothes I oft have seen, aye me my friend:
Pursue the murtherers, raise all the street

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: It shall not need, he stirs, give him breath.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Is there yet life, Horatio my dear boy,
Horatio! Horatio, what hast thou misdone,
To lose thy life when life was new begun?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Zeart a man had as good be hanged outright,
As to endure this clapping: shame to thy sex,
Perfidious perjured woman, where is thy shame?
How can thy modesty forbear to blush,
And knowest I know thee an adulteress?
Have not thy vows made thee my lawful wife
Before the face of heaven? where is thy shame?
But why speak I of shame to thee, whose face,
Is steeled with customed sin, whose thoughts want grace:
The custom of thy sin so lulls thy sense:
Women ne'er blush, though ne'er so foul the offence,
To break thy vow to me and straight to wed,
A doting stinkard.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: But hold your tongue,
Or by this light I will truss you up again,
Zeart rail on my wife, am I a stinkard,
Or do I dote? speak such another word,
And up you truss again, am I a stinkard?

sp.speaker: Bou,
sp.l: The knight your father is:

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why who denies it.
He supplants thee and I supplanted him.
Come come, you shall be friends come forgive her:
For by this light there is no remedy,
Unless you will betake you to my leavings.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Rather than so I will help you to a wife:
Rich, well born, and by some accounted fair,
And for the worth of her Virginity,
I dare presume to pawn my honesty:
What say you to Constantia Somerfield?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Dost know where she is boy?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I do, nay more,
If he but swear to embrace her constant love,
I will fetch her to this place.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: He shall do it boy,
He shall do it, go fetch her boy, foot my father,
Stand to it now old wench, stand to it now.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Now fresh and youthful as the month of May,
I will bid my Bride good morrow, Musicians on,
Lightly, lightly, and by my knighthoods spur,
This year you shall have my protection,
And yet not buy your livery coats yourselves:
God morrow Bride, fresh, fresh, as the month of May,
I come to kiss thee on thy wedding day.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Saving your tale sir, I will show you how,
So merrily singes the Cuckoo:
The truth is, I have laid my knife aboard,
The widow sir is wedded.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Ha,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Bedded.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: ha:

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Why my good father what should you do with a wife?
Would you be crested? will you needs thrust your head
In one of Vulcans Helmets? will you perforce
Wear a City cap and a Court feather?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Villain, slave, thou hast wronged my wife.

sp.speaker: VV. S.
sp.l: not so,
Speak my good wench, have I not done thee right.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I find no fault, and I protest Sir Oliuer.
I would not have lost the last two hours sleep,
I had by him, for all the wealth you have.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Villain slave, I will hang thee by the statute,
Thou hast two wives.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Be not so furious sir,
I have but this, the other was my whore,
Which now is married to an honest Lawyer.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Thou villain slave thou hast abused thy father.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Your son i'faith, your very son i'faith,
The villain boy has one trick of his sire,
Has firked away the wench, has pierced the hogshead,
And knows by this the vintage.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You could not love the widow but her wealth.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: The devil take my soul but I did love her.

sp.speaker: Taf,
sp.l: That oath doth show you are a Northern Knight,
And of all men alive, I will never trust,
A Northern man in love.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: And why? and why slut.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Because the first word he speaks is the Devil
Take his soul, and who will give him trust,
That once has given his soul unto the Devil.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: She says most true father, the soul once gone,
The best part of a man is gone.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And i'faith
If the best part of a man be once gone,
The rest of the body is not worth a rush,
Though it be ne'er so handsome.

div2.stage: Enter La, Somerfield, Throte & Beard bound, & Iu. Tutch.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: Bring them away.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: How now?
My Lawyer pinioned I begin to stink
Already.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: Cheater my daughter.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: She is mad.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: My wife sir, my wife.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: They are mad, stark mad,
I am sorry sir you have lost those happy wits
By which you lived so well. The air grows cold,
Therefore I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: La. So.
sp.l: Stay him officers,
Sir it is not your tricks of wit can carry it.
Officers attach him, and this Gentleman,
For stealing away my heir.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: You do me wrong,
Zart I never saw your heir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: That is a lie,
You stole her, and by chance I married her.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: God give you joy sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ask the Butler else,
Therefore widow release me, for by no law,
Statute or book case, of Uicesimo
Edwardi Secundi, nor by the Statute
Of Tricesimo Henrici sexti,
Nor by any book case of decimo
Of the late Queen, am I accessory,
Part, or party confederate, abetter,
Helper, seconder, persuader, forwarder,
Principal or maintainer of this late theft:
But by law, I forward, and she willing,
Clapped up the match, and by a good Statute
Of Decimo tertio Richardi quarti,
She is my leeful lawful, and my true
Married wife, teste Lieutenant Beard.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Who lives would think that you could prate so fast,
Your hands being bound behind you, foot he talks
With as much ease as if he were in his shirt.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I am witness thou hadst the heir.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: So am I.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: And so is my man Dash.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Hear me but speak,
Sit you as Judges, undo the Lawyers hands,
That he may freely act, and I will be bound
That William Smalshanke shall put your Throte to silence,
And overthrow him at his own weapon.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Agreed, take each his place, and hear the case
Argued betwixt them two.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Now Throte or never, stretch yourself.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Fear not

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: here stand I for my client, this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I for the widow.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Begin.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Right worshipful
I say that William Small-shanke mad-man,
Is by a Statute made in Octauo
Of Richard Cordelion guilty to the law
Of felony, for stealing this Ladies heir,
That he stole her, the proof is most pregnant,
He brought her to my house, confessed himself,
He made great means to steal her, I liked her,
(And finding him a novice) truth to tell,
Married hermyself, and as I said,
By a Statute Richardi Quarti,
She is my lawful wife.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: For my client,
I say the wench brought unto your house,
Was not the daughter to rich Somerfield.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: What proof of that

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: This gentleman.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Tut tut
He is a party in the cause, but sir,
If it were not the daughter to this good widow,
Who was it? answer that.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: An arrant whore
Which you have married, and she is run
Away with all your Jewels, this is true:
And this Lieutenant Beard can testify,
It was the wench I kept in Hofier-lane.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What was it she?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Speak sirrah Beard, if all he says be true,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: She said, she was a Punk, a Rampant whore,
Which in her time had been the cause of parting
Some fourteen bawds; he kept her in the Suburbs,
Yet I do think this wench was not the same.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: The case is clear with me.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: O strange.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sir, sir,
This is not true, how lived you in the Suburbs,
And scaped so many searches?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I answer,
That most Constables in out-parishes
Are bawds themselves; by which we scaped the searches.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: This is most strange.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: What is become of this woman?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That know not I. As I was squiring her
A long the street, Master Small-shanke set upon me,
Beat me down, and took away the maid,
Which I suppose was daughter to the widow.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: A lies, let me be hanged if he lie not.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: What confusion is this.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Bring them forward,
God preserve your worship. If it like you Madam,
We were commanded by our deputy,
That if we took a woman in the watch,
To bring her straight to you. And hearing there
You were come hither, hither we brought them.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: The one is my son, I do acknowledge him,
What woman's that.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: The widows daughter sir,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Blood is he gulled too.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: My brother stole her first,
Throte cozened him, and I had cozened Throte,
Had not the Constable took us in the watch,
She is the widows daughter, had I had luck,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: And my espoused wife.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: Unmask her face,
My daughter I defy her.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Your worships wife,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am gulled and abused, and by a Statute
Of Triceffimo of the late Queen,
I will Star-chamber you all for cozenage,
And be by law divorced.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Sir it will not hold,
She is your leeful, lawful, and true wedded wife,
Teste Lieutenant Beard.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Wast you that brake my head?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: But why shouldest think much to die a Cuckold,
Being born a Knave? as good Lawyers as you
Scorn not horns.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am gulled, aye me accursed!
Why should the harmless man be vexed with horns,
When women most deserve them?

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: I will show you sir,
The husband is the wives head, and I pray
Where should the horns stand but upon the head:
Why wert not thou begot (thou foolish knave)
By a poor Summoner, on a Sergeants widow?
Wert not thou a Puritan, and put in trust
To gather relief for the distressed Geneua,
And didst not thou leave thy poor brethren,
And run away with all the money, speak,
Was not that thy first rising? go,
You are well coupled by Jove ye are, she is
But a younger sister newly come to town,
She is currant mettle, not a penny the worse
For a little use, whole within the Ring,
By my soul.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Will he take her thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Yes faith, upon her promise of amendment.

sp.speaker: I. Tut.
sp.l: The Lawyer is gold.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Am I thus overreached, to have a wife,
And not of the best neither?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good sir be content,
A Lawyer should make all things right and straight,
All lies but in the handling, I may prove
A wife that shall deserve your best of love.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Take her Throte, you have a better jewel now
Than ever, kiss her, kiss her man, all friends.

sp.speaker: La. S:
sp.l: Yet in this happy close, I still have lost
My only daughter.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Where is thy Page Boutcher?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Here I present the Page: and that all doubts,
May here be cleared, here in my proper shape,
That all your joys may be complete and full,
I must make one, with pardon gentle mother,
Since all our friends so happily are met,
Here will I choose a husband: this be the man,
Whom since I left your house in shape of Page,
I still have followed.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Foot would I had known so much,
I would have been bold to have lain with your page.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Say am I welcome.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: As is my life and soul,

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.l: Heaven give you joy,
Since all so well succeeds, take my consent,

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: Then are we all paired, I and my lass,
You and your wife, the lawyer and his wench,
And father fall you aborde of the widow,
But then my brother.

sp.speaker: T. S.
sp.l: Faith I am a fool.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: That is all one; If God had not made
Some elder-brothers fools, how should witty
Younger brothers be maintained,
Strike up Music, let us have an old song,
Since all my tricks have found so good success,
We will sing, dance, dice, and drink down heaviness.

sp.speaker: Epilogus.
sp.l: Thus two hours have brought to end,
What many tedious hours have penned,
He dares not glory nor distrust,
But he (as other writers must)
Submits the censures of his pains
To those whose wit and nimble brains,
Are able best to judge: and as for some,
Who filled with malice, hither come
To belch their poison on his labour,
Of them he doth entreat no favour,
But bids them hang, or soon amend,
For worth shall still itself defend,
And for ourselves we do desire,
You will breath on us that growing fire,
By which in time we may attain,
Like favours which some others gain:
For be assured our loves shall tend,
To equal theirs, if not transcend.
